Both former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge have expressed optimism about Benteke's impact at Liverpool, citing his physical presence and goal-scoring ability.

The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools, involving 671 schools, found no clear evidence that tablet devices improve academic performance. Tablets are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with the highest usage in academy schools. The study predicts an increase in tablet use in schools from 430,000 to nearly 900,000 devices between 2014 and 2016. Despite no definitive link to improved results, tablets are reported to motivate disengaged students and increase family involvement when taken home. A separate study indicated that touch-screen devices aid boys and poorer pupils in reading. The widespread use of tablets at home and school reflects their integration into young people's daily lives, with many using them for social media and other activities into the night.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, showcasing the evolution of childhood in Liverpool. Curated by Kay Jones, the exhibit includes images of children at play and at work, highlighting both joyful and challenging aspects of their lives. A notable photo from 1887 shows the Rollo children dressed for a fancy dress ball, while another from around 1900 depicts a young maid. The exhibition, which runs until September 25, offers a poignant look at social history through the lens of childhood experiences in the city.

Centre-back Anderson, aged 27, has terminated his contract with Barrow by mutual consent to move to a rival National League team, with a potential match against Barrow on 18 February. Anderson previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, has been signed by the Gulls after being recommended by Micky Adams, pending international clearance. Keating has experience with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson's leadership and stature, and described Keating as young and eager to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points clear of the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

The new Bolivian law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental consent, reflecting the country's economic needs as one of South America's poorest nations. It also increases penalties for violence against children, setting a 30-year sentence for child homicide. The legislation, signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales, aims to balance local realities with international treaties. Over 500,000 children in Bolivia already work to support their families, often in harsh conditions such as mines and agriculture. The government hopes this law will help combat extreme poverty, despite the International Labour Organisation's recommendation against child labor under 15, with a possible exception for developing countries at age 14. The ILO is reviewing the law for compliance with international standards.

A 50-year-old woman, after experiencing sudden nausea and aches at home, researched her symptoms online and identified them as potential signs of a heart attack. She took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, who found a 99% blockage in an artery and inserted a stent. The woman, identified as an actress from shows like Drop Dead Diva and Will and Grace, described her ordeal as a "widow maker" heart attack on her blog. She did not call emergency services but urged other women to recognize the symptoms and seek immediate help. The incident occurred after she helped a woman at her home in Nyack, near New York. Additionally, she recently hosted The Rosie Show, which was cancelled due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed at a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, around 00:30 GMT on Saturday. The stabbing occurred during a scuffle in an alleyway after a group of youths attempted to enter the party and were initially denied. Che, who was invited to the party described as well-run with adults present, was not involved in the initial altercation but was targeted later. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Police have arrested a 21-year-old man on suspicion of murder, and two boys aged 15 and 16 on the same charge, while a 14-year-old was arrested for possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage discusses a reorganization of patient diagnosis in Denmark, particularly for cancer cases with non-obvious symptoms, inspired by poor cancer survival statistics over 15 years ago. A team from Wales visited Aarhus, Denmark, to study this new approach. The Danish model introduced three diagnostic routes: 1) Fast-track for patients with clear cancer symptoms, 2) Diagnosis centers for patients with undiagnosable symptoms by GPs, offering quick tests and scans, and 3) "Yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms to quickly rule out serious diseases. These changes have improved organization without overwhelming the system, leading to better survival rates and Denmark catching up with other Scandinavian countries. The model emphasizes collaboration between GPs and specialists, and there is potential for Wales to learn from Denmark's approach.

The UK government has replaced the OFT with Powys, which won a bidding process to oversee estate agent regulations, receiving £170,000 annually. Powys will issue warnings and bans to dishonest agents or those breaching estate agent laws. Complaints about estate agents are handled by local trading standards, who may refer cases to Powys if the Estate Agents Act is violated. James Munro from Powys council leads this initiative and sees potential for future contracts.

The NHS Employers, following a Nuffield Trust review, has approved a plan to expand the roles of nurses and other health staff to address shortages in doctors and GPs. The review highlighted successful examples of nurses substituting for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. This shift is seen as beneficial due to the increasing focus on managing long-term conditions. However, unions and medical professionals caution against using this as a quick fix, emphasizing the need for proper funding and training to ensure quality care and support for existing staff. The plan aims to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce to improve patient care and provide more rewarding roles for staff.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath after a crash at 03:00 GMT, affecting the A36 until its reopening at 14:00 GMT. The closure caused significant disruptions to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations into the collision are ongoing. First, the bus operator, reported that while some services resumed normally, full service was expected to be restored by the evening commute. First's managing director, James Freeman, thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts in managing the situation.

The passage discusses a dispute between Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) regarding the environmental impact of the proposed £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon on fish populations. NRW estimated that the lagoon would result in the death of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually, based on what they claim is the "best available evidence." TLP contested these figures, arguing they lacked a "clear scientific basis" and were "unrealistic and grossly misleading." TLP's own modeling suggested a maximum impact of 2% mortality across all fish species. The controversy centers around NRW's refusal to share its methodology with TLP. The Swansea project is seen as a pilot for larger tidal lagoons planned for other locations. The Welsh Government supports the project but awaits clarity from the UK government on its position, which is expected soon following a review. NRW defended its stance, asserting confidence in its evidence and methodology, which have been reviewed by independent and internal experts.

The establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland was announced by DETI Minister Arlene Foster. This body, modeled after Scotland Food and Drink, aims to enhance coordination and strategic marketing efforts within the agri-food sector, which employs nearly 100,000 people. The initiative is supported by Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill, who acknowledges its potential to boost export-led growth but also notes possible implications for existing organizations. The Agri-Food Strategy Board will develop this new marketing entity.

The Woodland Trust has organized a tree planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, inviting the public to plant 40,000 native UK trees in memory of the 40,000 people from Ireland who died in WW1. This event is part of a larger four-year project to plant millions of trees across four new woods in the UK, commemorating those who fell in the war. The project, described as one of the trust's most ambitious, uses the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." At Brackfield Wood, participants are encouraged to contribute to creating a lasting tribute that will include wildflowers and serve as a habitat for wildlife, as well as a place for reflection. The event is set for a Saturday afternoon, with the trust providing saplings and advising attendees to wear appropriate footwear. Brackfield Wood is located seven miles from Derry city, with limited parking available.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book described as "emotionally exhausting and powerful" by judge Alison Graham. The award was given at the start of the Harrogate crime writing festival, where US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution award for her work on the VI Warshawski series. Ann Cleeves, the festival's programming chair, praised the strength of the shortlist and highlighted Hilary's winning novel for its fine and tight writing. The novel, "Someone Else's Skin," is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and addresses domestic violence and honour crime. Paretsky's impact on crime fiction was noted for introducing a strong female protagonist and founding Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, suffered a broken finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, cutting short his stint with the team. Steve Rhodes, Worcestershire's director of cricket, expressed disappointment over the injury, noting it was a significant setback to their season. Santner, who debuted in Test cricket in 2015, is set to return to Worcestershire following the ICC Trophy in June. He is eager to make up for lost time and contribute effectively in the upcoming season. Additionally, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in 2008 by a speeding car on a dual carriageway in Kiev while trying to hail a taxi. The coroner at Exeter County Hall, Dr Elizabeth Earland, concluded that Pring was unlawfully killed, influenced by circumstantial evidence suggesting the car involved had stolen license plates and did not stop after the incident. Pring's wife, Ganna Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger and met Pring online in 2006, was suspected by Pring's family of orchestrating his death to inherit his assets. Ziuzina attempted to claim his assets shortly after his death and was found to have sold his possessions and moved money from his accounts. She was also discovered to be having an affair. Despite Ukrainian police initially closing the case, it was reopened as a murder inquiry in 2011, though it remains inactive.

Charlie Fearns, a young boy from Merseyside, needs to travel to Seattle, USA, for experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital due to the failure of his previous transplant and the unavailability of further treatment options in the UK. His family was devastated by the initial transplant's failure but overjoyed when an anonymous donor covered the costs of the new treatment. The donation was confirmed via an email from the hospital, and Charlie's treatment is set to begin soon, with the exact date to be determined next week. Both of Charlie's parents expressed immense gratitude for the donor's generosity.

The passage discusses Apple's response to the theft of celebrities' intimate photos from iCloud, believed to be facilitated by third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple introduced a two-step verification process as an opt-in security measure to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud. This process requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering a username and password on an unfamiliar device. If access is denied, a 14-character recovery key can be used, though it poses risks if lost or stolen. Previously, this security was not applied to iCloud backups, allowing hackers to access data despite two-step verification being enabled elsewhere. Elcomsoft's owner confirmed that Apple's new measures block his software's previous capabilities. Security experts suggest that two-factor authentication should be a default setting across tech companies, not just an option. Apple plans to encourage users more aggressively to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, as stated by CEO Tim Cook, emphasizing the need for increased user awareness about security.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal for Mark Wright to buy 20% of Billericay football club are yet to be finalized. Wright, aged 30, is expected to become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is three points behind a play-off spot. Mark Wright, who finished second on 'I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here' in 2011, has a history of playing non-league football for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club's new owner, multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, is willing to invest £10,000 weekly and recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky, aged 35, in early March.

Mr Ashley, owner of a Derbyshire company and Newcastle United Football Club, has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse practices. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, chair of the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, sent a letter giving Mr Ashley until 21 March to respond. The letter mentions an invitation from Mr Ashley for the committee to meet at the company's base in Shirebrook, but notes that Mr Ashley has not accepted any of the alternative dates offered for a public meeting at Westminster. The committee is focused on the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage, and has warned of potential further action, including seeking House of Commons support for a contempt complaint if Mr Ashley does not agree to attend. Sports Direct has not commented on the issue, despite previous pledges to review worker rights under Mr Ashley's oversight.

The passage discusses a report titled "Putin. War," which was completed by colleagues of a murdered Russian opposition politician, led by Ilya Yashin. The report alleges that Russian President Vladimir Putin is responsible for waging war in Ukraine for personal gain, detailing the human and economic costs of the conflict. It claims that Russian military units and equipment were crucial in securing victories for pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine, contradicting Russia's official stance that any Russian involvement consists of volunteers. The report includes evidence from volunteer soldiers and a veteran who helped recruit them, noting high salaries for participants and estimating Russian spending on the conflict at 53 billion roubles. Despite the report's findings being available online and in some Russian media, public interest and the willingness to challenge the government's narrative remain limited. The opposition struggles with distribution and fears among publishers, while many Russians accept their country's involvement as support for independence from Kiev. The report's impact is uncertain, with fears it may not significantly influence public opinion or lead to protests, similar to previous reports by the late Boris Nemtsov on corruption and the Sochi Olympics.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was discovered deceased at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. The 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn, Rotherham, died from head injuries according to a post-mortem. Following his death, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses tensions between the Welsh government and the UK government regarding the handling of Brexit, specifically around the Article 50 letter. Carwyn Jones, the Welsh First Minister, expressed frustration over not being shown the letter before its publication and not being involved in its drafting, highlighting a lack of respect towards devolved administrations. Despite this, UK Prime Minister Theresa May mentioned Wales in the letter, promising consultation on the devolution of powers post-Brexit, with an expectation of increased decision-making power for devolved administrations. However, specifics on which powers, such as farming or economic aid, and whether funding would accompany these powers remain unclear. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's approach, emphasizing that the government has been engaging with Wales and acting in the interest of the whole UK. The passage also hints at potential political motivations and the upcoming Great Repeal Bill, which might provide further clarity on the devolution of powers.

In Newry, on Nursery Drive and Parkhead, two cars were damaged during an incident on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his appalled reaction to the attacks on PSNI officers and the community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne reported that the police were attacked while performing their duties. They also urged parents to monitor their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was removed from his position last year due to employee complaints and allegations of misusing company funds. The company's board stated in a San Francisco court filing that they do not expect him to return. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, claimed that many statements against Charney were false and accused the company of invading Charney's privacy to extort and gain leverage over him. The court documents revealed evidence of Charney sending illicit emails to female employees and making racially derogatory remarks, in response to his defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. The company stated that Charney repeatedly violated its sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies, making it unlikely for any board to rehire him due to the risk to the company and its shareholders. Recently, American Apparel obtained a restraining order against Charney, preventing him from making negative public statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The upcoming basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30 to 19:30 BST. The match is set to take place at the Copper Box in Stratford, which is significant for GB guard Teddy Okereafor, who is excited to play there. This game is GB's only home match before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017, starting in September in Istanbul, Turkey. Greece previously defeated GB 92-64 in Patras, but will be missing three players for this rematch, giving GB a chance for revenge. After this game, GB will travel to Poland for a four-team tournament as their final preparation for EuroBasket.

The passage recounts the author's experience with the launch of the iPhone in 2007, highlighting the initial difficulty in obtaining the device for a news piece due to its high demand and limited availability. The author managed to borrow an iPhone from Apple's marketing chief, Phil Schiller, to showcase on the Ten O’Clock News, which led to criticism for giving undue prominence to the product launch. The author defended the coverage by comparing the iPhone's potential impact to that of the Model T Ford, suggesting significant technological shifts merit news coverage. Reflecting on the iPhone's influence over the subsequent decade, the author acknowledges its transformative effect on various industries, particularly photography, and credits Steve Jobs for revolutionizing mobile device usability. The passage concludes by recognizing the iPhone's role in initiating the mobile connected era, despite initial skepticism, and notes the continued innovation by other tech giants like Amazon and Google.

In Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, near Victor Avenue, tests confirmed that all cats in the area had ingested a toxic substance, identified as antifreeze in at least one case. Seven-month-old cat Meereen died after showing symptoms of poisoning, including shivering, foaming at the mouth, and attempting to vomit. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, reported the cat's death, which occurred three days after veterinary treatment. Over the past two weeks, four other cats in the area have also died. The RSPCA is unsure if the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and has urged residents to safely store pesticides and chemicals, particularly antifreeze, due to its common use in cars during this time of year.

The passage discusses the current economic and political situation in Greece, where the Syriza government, led by Alexis Tsipras, is preparing to implement further austerity and liberalization measures as part of a new bailout agreement with the eurozone and possibly the IMF. Despite these measures, which include painful VAT increases, pension cuts, and anticipated reductions in farm subsidies, there are no public demonstrations in Athens. The text suggests that the lack of protests might be due to the public awaiting the full details of the concessions Tsipras has made to secure €86 billion in new credit. 

Tourism in Greece remains strong, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year, an increase from the previous year. The passage speculates that tourists might be drawn by the prospect of witnessing a historic euro break-up or simply by Greece's appeal as a holiday destination compared to regions affected by conflict.

The passage also highlights the economic challenges Greece faces, including a near-death economic experience in July that led to bank closures and a collapse in economic activity. This situation has turned Syriza into followers of the "there is no alternative" (TINA) doctrine. Despite failing to end fiscal austerity and causing monetary austerity through continued bank restrictions, Tsipras remains popular.

The text concludes by emphasizing the need for creditors to significantly reduce Greece's debt burden for the new bailout to lead to genuine recovery, warning against triumphalism and calling for debt forgiveness from Brussels and Berlin.

Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in EastEnders, is returning for a brief stint to coincide with the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Peggy returned to Albert Square to inform her son Phil that her cancer had returned and will die from the disease in upcoming scenes. Kemp's return aims to reunite the Mitchell family, including brothers Grant and Phil, for Peggy's last moments. This storyline marks a significant event in the soap's history, bringing back the iconic character Grant Mitchell to say goodbye to his mother and reconnect with family and past loves.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. During the trial at Newcastle Crown Court, it was revealed that Dhillon had become obsessed with the 24-year-old. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, expressed their immediate suspicion of Dhillon upon being informed of their daughter's death by police. Sue Hills felt guilty for reassuring Alice that ignoring Dhillon would resolve the issue, despite warnings from her other daughter, Emma, about the severity of the situation. Alice's parents did not fully grasp the seriousness of the stalking. Dhillon, aged 26, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to at least 22 years in prison. In response to their daughter's death, Alice's parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking, aiming to remember Alice for her vibrant and cheerful personality.

The French company EDF, primarily financing the £18bn Hinkley Point C project in Somerset, approved the funding, but the UK government, led by Business Secretary Greg Clark, decided to review the project further before giving its backing. This decision came right after EDF's board approval and led to the cancellation of a visit by EDF's CEO Vincent de Rivaz to the site. The project, which involves significant Chinese investment covering one third of the costs, has raised concerns about environmental impact, escalating costs, and foreign government involvement. Critics, including environmental groups like Greenpeace, argue that the project represents poor value for money and could harm EDF financially, as evidenced by resignations of key EDF board members citing financial risks. The project is expected to supply 7% of the UK's electricity and has been described as beneficial for both French and British nuclear industries, though it faces challenges due to EDF's financial situation. The Hinkley Point C project has a long history, with key milestones including government approval for construction in 2013 and an investment agreement with China in 2015. Delays and uncertainties have been a recurring theme, with the latest government review causing concern over energy supply and costs, as well as the potential impact on Anglo-French relations post-Brexit.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales now directly asks for the name of the person with whom a spouse has committed adultery, a change from the older version which had a space for "co-respondents." Family lawyers, including Margaret Heathcote and Georgina Hamblin, express concerns that naming a third party increases conflict and complexity in divorce proceedings. Despite guidance indicating it's not usually necessary to name the third party, the form's design may encourage people to do so, potentially leading to more legal complications and costs. In 2015, adultery was cited in 12,148 out of over 100,000 divorces in England and Wales. The Ministry of Justice clarifies that while it's possible to name the person involved in adultery, there is no obligation to do so.

The passage discusses the tension between environmental policies and the commercial forestry industry in Wales. Britain is a major wood importer, and there is a push for commercial forestry to invest in woodland creation. However, since 2001, Wales has lost 16,000 hectares of commercial forest, which needs replanting to meet demands. The forestry industry, valued at over £450 million annually to the Welsh economy, is split between management by Natural Resources Wales and private companies. There is a conflict as ministers favor native broadleaf species and public access, while conservationists criticize commercial forests for harming wildlife. Logistical challenges include difficult access to some forests and conflicts with rural communities over timber transport. The Welsh government aims for a balance through initiatives like the Glastir scheme and the Woodlands for Wales strategy, which seeks to enhance landscapes, support communities, and bolster the industry. Martin Bishop from Confor highlights the bureaucratic hurdles in creating new woodlands and the insufficient planting rate of 90 hectares last year against a needed 20,000 hectares annually to meet long-term targets, driven by a strong market demand for timber.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street. Emergency services responded around 16:40, and he was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition remains serious.

Capt Oleg Kornienko, a defence attaché, awarded Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoys veterans, including 91-year-old Able seaman Charles Lewis from Hampshire, who felt honored despite not viewing himself as a hero. The convoys, crucial for resupplying the Soviet Union during WWII, faced severe conditions and threats from German forces, resulting in significant losses by May 1945. The Russian Embassy emphasized the convoys' role in enabling the defeat of the Germans on the Eastern Front, highlighting the wartime alliance between Russia and Britain. Initially blocked by the Foreign Office due to rules against foreign medals for acts over five years old, the medals were eventually allowed as an exception. The British Government also introduced the Arctic Star in 2012 to recognize these veterans. President Vladimir Putin presented the first Ushakov medals during his visit to London in June 2013.

HM Inspectorate of Probation identified significant delays and leniency in the enforcement of unpaid work sentences for offenders, with one case showing an offender completing only 16 hours in 17 months. The report, based on 100 cases and interviews with 86 offenders, criticized the management and delivery of these sentences, suggesting they were often viewed merely as punishment rather than an opportunity for rehabilitation. In 2014, about 70,000 offenders were assigned unpaid work for various offenses. The government's initiative, rebranded as "community payback" and involving tasks like garden maintenance and litter-picking, aimed to instill public confidence in community sentences as a tough alternative to prison. However, organizational challenges persist, particularly in ensuring offenders with chaotic lifestyles attend work on time. The report made 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing instances where offenders are turned away despite arriving on time and tailoring work objectives to offenders' circumstances. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the issues and committed to implementing the report's recommendations to enhance rehabilitation effectiveness.

The passage discusses comedian Russell Brand being labeled a "hypocrite" by The Sun newspaper for advocating economic and political revolution to aid the poor while living in a luxurious London home. This accusation is not new for Brand, who has been criticized similarly before. The article mentions an incident where Brand was confronted by a Channel 4 News reporter about his living situation while supporting a campaign against the displacement of east London estate residents. Brand reacted negatively to the question and walked off. The passage also touches on Brand's past responses to such criticisms, where he acknowledges his wealth and fame but emphasizes the need for systemic change and personal transformation, arguing that his wealth does not negate the validity of his concerns about economic inequality and ecological issues. Brand has not responded to inquiries about potential legal action against The Sun and its owner, Rupert Murdoch, but has been active on social media discussing the accusations.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the human genome mapping into a competitive race, which led to criticism from the scientific community. Despite his controversial approach and self-confidence, his work significantly accelerated the genome mapping process. After the human genome project, Venter focused on creating a synthetic life form, Synthia, at the J Craig Venter Institute, a project spanning over a decade and detailed in the journal Science. Venter's early life included a period of poor academic performance and military service during the Vietnam War, which influenced his urgency in scientific pursuits. His career progressed from the National Institute of Health, where he innovated gene sequencing techniques using RNA, to founding private institutes like The Institute for Genomic Research and Celera Genomics. These ventures not only challenged traditional scientific methods but also led to significant discoveries, including the first complete genome of a free-living organism and the human genome. Venter's work extended to marine biology with the Sorcerer II project, aiming to sequence ocean microbes' genomes. His synthetic life project, while controversial, holds potential for industrial applications and environmental benefits.

The passage discusses a survey conducted in England about school lunches, revealing that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school. Half of the surveyed parents reported their children requesting school-tried foods at home. The survey, involving around 1,000 parents, identified carrots, sweetcorn, and peas as the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were less favored. The research was commissioned by England's School Food Trust following concerns from parents about children's fussiness with food, as indicated by a Mumsnet survey. School meals are seen as a way to encourage children to try new foods and increase dietary variety, supported by positive peer pressure at school. School meals in England must meet strict nutritional guidelines, with about 40% of primary and slightly fewer secondary school children eating school lunches, compared to 46% in Scotland. The survey was conducted online from February 26 to March 5 among parents with children aged 4-17.

Álvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker, is currently playing at Euro 2016. He transferred to Juventus from Real Madrid in 2014, with Real retaining a buy-back option for up to 30m euros. Previously linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, Morata has scored three goals for Spain at the tournament. During his two-year stint at Juventus, he scored 27 goals, securing two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italia trophies. He also played in consecutive Champions League finals, coming off the bench in Real Madrid's 2014 victory and scoring in Juventus' 2015 loss to Barcelona. Morata began his career at Real Madrid, debuting at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the club.

Wilson returned to Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 and was released in May. During his second stint at Forest, he played 51 matches over four seasons. He has also played for Preston North End and Notts County. He is currently without a club.

The British supermarket giant Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business. Fresh & Easy, operating 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona since 2007, will see 50 stores closed as part of the deal. Tesco will loan the new business approximately £80m and the total cost to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand is £150m, part of which may be repaid. If Yucaipa turns the business profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake in it. This move comes after Tesco reported its first annual profit drop in 20 years in April.

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse but overcame it, considered representing France, and is now aiming to win a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Additionally, it mentions a special guide on how to get into martial arts.

The passage discusses the significant retreat of glaciers in the French Alps over the last four decades, as detailed in a new inventory by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie. Initially covering about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s, the glacier area reduced to approximately 275 sq km by the late 2000s, marking a 26% loss. This research, presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting, utilized map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual checks to ensure accuracy due to potential issues with debris cover and shadows in automatic delineation methods. The retreat is uneven across the region, with the southern Alps, including the Belledonne and Ecrins massifs, experiencing more significant losses compared to the northern Alps, such as the Mont Blanc Massif, which hosts the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace. The study attributes the varying retreat rates to differences in elevation and climatic conditions, with the north receiving more precipitation and cloud cover.

The Scottish women's national football team, led by players like Bayern Munich's forward Evans, is close to qualifying for the next summer's finals in the Netherlands after winning all five of their qualifiers. They are set to host Iceland, ranked just above them at 20th in the world, at Falkirk Stadium. A victory against Iceland would nearly guarantee Scotland's qualification, avoiding the need for a play-off, something they've struggled with in past attempts to reach major tournaments like Euro 2013 and the last World Cup. The outcome of the upcoming match and the return fixture in Reykjavik will likely determine the group winner. Evans, who has celebrated success in the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, emphasizes the emotional significance of potentially reaching the finals and the advantage of having Scottish players in top international leagues, enhancing the national team's performance.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger known for his Scottish independence campaign through the Wings Over Scotland blog, was arrested in the west of England following a harassment complaint from a woman in south London. The allegations pertain to online harassment over two years, specifically related to tweets from Campbell's Twitter account, which he claims are non-threatening. Released on bail, Campbell criticized media reports for encouraging speculation and innuendo. He plans to post less frequently on his blog due to circumstances beyond his control. The Metropolitan Police are continuing their investigation, with Campbell's bail set to continue until mid-September.

Peta has proposed replacing Skegness's mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, with a fish mascot named "Skegness - A Happy Plaice," arguing that the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway to promote Skegness as a seaside destination, features the slogan "Skegness is so bracing." Dawn Carr from Peta criticized the mascot for representing the mutilation and killing of sea animals, suggesting a rebranding opportunity for Skegness as a progressive holiday destination. However, Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, defended the Jolly Fisherman, stating it is loved by the community and does not portray animal cruelty, and indicated that while Peta's suggestion would be considered, there was little support for changing the mascot.

In a rugby match, Georgia initially took the lead with a try from Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland quickly surged ahead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg, and Hamish Watson. Scotland dominated possession and territory, leading to a significant points difference by halftime. Georgia managed a second try through Lobzhanidze from a strong scrum performance in the second half, but Scotland responded with another try from Hogg, finishing the game with a strong lead. Key players for Scotland included Hogg, who scored twice, and Greig Laidlaw, who was instrumental in conversions and penalties. The match showcased Scotland's control and effective counter-attacks, despite Georgia's efforts and strong scrum play.

In a rugby match, Widnes secured a 38-24 victory over Castleford. Widnes led 14-6 at halftime with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, while Castleford's Paddy Flynn, on loan from Widnes, scored against his parent club. In the second half, despite Flynn scoring twice more and Castleford mounting a late comeback with tries from Larne Patrick and Luke Gale, Widnes maintained their lead with additional tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (twice), and Joe Mellor. The win moved Widnes to seventh place, above Wakefield, while Castleford, despite the loss, stayed in sixth, one point ahead of Widnes. Castleford faced their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from Guantanamo Bay after a US review panel determined he was not a significant threat. Detained since 2002 on suspicion of al-Qaeda and Taliban links, which he denied, Odah had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. He returned to Kuwait, expressing no bitterness but joy at going home, according to his lawyer. His release, the first since May, reduces Guantanamo's inmate count to 148. Odah faces a year at a rehabilitation center in Kuwait as per his release terms. The Kuwaiti government advocated for the release of its detainees, while President Obama has promised to close the facility opened post-9/11.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle of Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, was marked by thousands at Hyde Park Corner and a parade of up to 400 at the Cenotaph in London. Services were also held at Westminster Abbey, where the first Anzac Day was observed in 1916 with King George V in attendance. The day honors the sacrifices of Australians and New Zealanders in all wars, with significant participation from expatriates and visitors. The ceremony included wreath-laying, speeches reflecting on the Gallipoli landings, and the singing of national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK. The Gallipoli campaign, remembered for its brutality, aimed to remove the Ottoman Empire from the war.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer, has rejoined Premiership club St Mirren and is set to possibly debut against Alloa in the Championship. Last season, he scored nine goals at Dundee and has been maintaining his fitness by playing for the U20s and training hard. With nearly 400 senior appearances and experience at clubs like Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers, Clarkson is eager to contribute to St Mirren, who are currently eighth in the Championship. He aims to help the team win games and climb the league table. Clarkson has also represented Scotland internationally, earning two caps and scoring once in 2008.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was acquired by food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. Concerns about the existing workers' pension scheme were alleviated after productive talks, with guarantees that all current agreements, including the alternative pension scheme established since the closure of the final salary scheme in 2004, would be honored under the new ownership. Boparan's strategy includes restoring Bernard Matthews to profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and expanding to process chicken as well as turkeys.

The council discussed issues with a new vessel at a scrutiny meeting, deciding to offer free crossings at Cowes until July 2 to address the problems and gather feedback. The ferry, launched on May 14, experienced multiple issues including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. Additionally, cars were damaged during embarkation and disembarkation. The council ordered a project review by auditors. Local businesses, feeling the impact of these disruptions, are seeking compensation similar to that provided for damaged cars. Transport councillor Ian Ward mentioned that compensation is under discussion and described the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems, which include electrical issues now fixed and vehicle scraping problems to be resolved with ramp extensions. He also noted that groundings were due to seamanship issues, which have been addressed.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights the industry's strong support for leaving the EU due to dissatisfaction with the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The House of Lords report warns that the fishing communities risk being marginalized in Brexit negotiations, despite their small contribution to the GDP and employment. The report emphasizes the need for continued market access to the EU, which may require allowing EU boats to fish in UK waters. It also suggests retaining certain elements of the CFP post-Brexit, such as scientific-based quotas, and notes the potential for different fisheries management regimes in the UK's constituent countries. Despite these challenges, many in the industry are optimistic about regaining control over UK waters and becoming a leading fish-exporting nation, as evidenced by recent favorable quota adjustments under the CFP.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or allowing images of young boys in erotic poses to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014. He received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, and was required to participate in a sex offender program. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, Geaney was removed from the teaching profession's register due to his actions being deemed fundamentally incompatible with the standards expected of a teacher. The hearing highlighted the lengthy duration and volume of his offending behavior, suggesting a pattern rather than an isolated incident, and concluded there was a high likelihood of recurrence. Consequently, he was found unfit to teach and barred from re-registering for two years.

Following a fire on March 2 at a site on Duncan Street, firefighters were present for several days, leading to reduced train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and later revoked their environmental permit, effective from August 7, unless appealed by the same date. The company, operated by Asset and Land Group, was described as "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS), who had visited the site nine times in the last year. Concerns about the potential impact of a fire were raised by GMFRS to the EA in February, prompting joint visits and subsequent enforcement action. The cause of the fire remains undetermined, and the company must remove all waste from the site.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is making efforts to comply with the schedule for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline due to attacks on shipments. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only 4% removed so far. The US and Russia have expressed concerns and set deadlines for the completion of the transfer and destruction of these weapons by June. Amidst ongoing conflict, the Syrian government denies using barrel bombs in Aleppo, where significant civilian casualties have been reported, and also denies that rebels have taken control of Aleppo's central prison, despite claims from opposition groups and the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights that the prison, holding 3,000 detainees, is now under rebel control.

In the cricket match at Old Trafford, England decisively defeated Pakistan, leveling the series. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, securing their second largest victory by runs against Pakistan. Joe Root, promoted to bat at number three, was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, scoring 105 and 76 not out himself. Pakistan struggled, batting only 63 and 70 overs in their innings on a pitch offering little to bowlers. Former players and commentators lauded England's performance, predicting further success in the series. Pakistan, led by Misbah-ul-Haq, acknowledged their poor shot selection and lack of confidence, with only Misbah and Asad Shafiq scoring over 50 in the series so far. Pakistan is set to play a tour game before the third Test at Edgbaston.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review on the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She aims to gather experiences from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira has observed both the positive impacts of high-quality care and the negative effects of poor care across Wales. Her review will assess various aspects of life in care homes, including physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care environment. Her team will also engage with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. However, the Care Forum Wales expressed disappointment over the lack of a care home expert on the review's main advisory panel, suggesting a missed opportunity for more inclusive partnership in the review process.

Paul Sheerin, aged 39, has transitioned from player-manager at Arbroath to a new role at Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Previously a midfielder for the Dons, Sheerin led Arbroath to win the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011, but they were relegated to Scottish League Two after the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's CEO Duncan Fraser noted that Derek McInnes selected Sheerin after a thorough process, and despite Arbroath's chairman John Christison's reluctance, he respected Sheerin's wish to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin has played for various Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, and earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as the top choice. The club faces the risk of relegation, which could make returning to the Premier League challenging due to the increased competitiveness of the Championship. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, has struggled since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, with frequent managerial changes diluting the 'Swansea Way'. Curtis believes the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and emphasizes the club's history and significance to new players, referencing the documentary "Jack to a King".

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, transformed the human genome mapping into a competitive race, which led to criticism from the scientific community. Despite his controversial approach and self-confidence, Venter's work significantly accelerated the genome mapping process. After the human genome project, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in the organism Synthia, developed at the J Craig Venter Institute. Venter's early life included poor academic performance and military service in Vietnam, which influenced his urgency in scientific pursuits. His career progressed from the National Institute of Health, where he innovated gene sequencing techniques, to founding private institutes like The Institute for Genomic Research and Celera Genomics. His commercial approach to science, including the rapid sequencing of the human genome, brought both financial success and further controversy. Additionally, Venter has explored marine genomics through his yacht-based project, Sorcerer II, aiming to understand microbial genetics. His work on synthetic life, particularly with Synthia, aims to initiate a new industrial revolution by using cells for environmental benefits.

The Sutton Trust's report, conducted by the Boston Consulting Group, criticizes the quality and duration of many apprenticeships in England compared to other European countries like Germany. It highlights that out of 520,000 annual apprenticeship starts in England, fewer than 200,000 are at level three (equivalent to A-levels), and only 61,000 are for young people. In contrast, Germany offers 570,000 new apprenticeships for young people annually, with 90% at A-level equivalent. The report notes England's vocational system's complexity with 18,000 qualifications compared to Germany's 330, and points out that since 2010, over half of England's apprenticeships have been below level three and mostly for those over 25. The report calls for a radical expansion to 300,000 new starts per year, predominantly at level three for at least three years, and suggests limiting level two apprenticeships to 10%. It emphasizes the need for high-quality vocational education and better careers guidance. The Department for Education acknowledges ongoing reforms to improve apprenticeship standards, while the Association of Colleges supports the expansion but stresses the preservation of respected level two apprenticeships.

Sarah Storey, a 37-year-old British athlete, won a cycling time trial in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. This victory marks her 21st world title across cycling and swimming. Storey, who switched from swimming to cycling in 2005, has a total of 22 Paralympic medals, including 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze, earned over six Paralympic Games. She aims to add to her achievements at the upcoming Paralympics in Rio de Janeiro. Storey is set to compete for her 17th world title in the road race on the following Saturday.

Hereford United, known as the Bulls, were expelled from the Conference Premier due to unresolved financial issues, despite a dramatic last-day survival in the league. The club failed to meet multiple payment deadlines to clear debts amounting to £148,000 to football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle and current squad members. The Conference extended the deadline several times, but Hereford, under new owner Tommy Agombar, could not comply. Consequently, Chester was reinstated in the Conference Premier, taking Hereford's place. The financial troubles of Hereford, which began after relegation from the Football League in 2012, were compounded by declining attendance and significant debts, including over £70,000 owed to HMRC. Efforts by the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club for £1 and clear debts were not successful, leading to a sad outcome for the club and its supporters.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, earned 61 caps for England after debuting in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for the most caps for England's Under-21 team with 46 appearances, starting from 2004. His sole international goal was scored during a 5-0 win against Moldova in the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. Milner expressed his decision to retire from international football was based on common sense and wished success to Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral is to be private, followed by a public memorial service. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 CDs, including a complete cycle of Mozart's symphonies on period instruments. Notable among his recordings is the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, recognized as one of the top 20 recordings by BBC Music Magazine. He held various academic and artistic positions, including at Cambridge University, Harvard University, and as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. Colleagues and peers praised his generosity, academic prowess, and significant contributions to historically informed music performance.

The boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected, had to leave mainstream schooling due to difficulties coping. His parents sought a place in a special school, but all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full, leaving the family without a timeline for enrollment. The boy's isolation has been exacerbated by the system, as he misses social interaction. Recently, a new classroom assistant was hired at a local special school, raising hopes that the boy might start there soon. However, his mother is concerned about the capacity issues affecting other families. The Education Authority, while unable to comment on individual cases due to privacy concerns, is reviewing the need for special school places across Northern Ireland, aiming to improve placement availability starting in 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over Newport Gwent Dragons and views Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue. Newport County, who also use the stadium, have a lease until 2023 that prioritizes their fixtures if they remain in the Football League. The takeover bid will be voted on by shareholders on May 9. Newport County secured a 10-year lease in 2013 upon promotion to the Football League. Both Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements at Rodney Parade. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which conflicts with Football League regulations. On the field, Newport County is close to securing their position in League Two, needing a win and a loss from Hartlepool to avoid relegation, which would be detrimental to the club and the city of Newport.

The passage details the personal journey of a man who was kidnapped at 15 by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels during Sierra Leone's civil war in 1991. He endured severe indoctrination and violence, including being forced to kill under the influence of drugs like marijuana and cocaine. After escaping, he struggled in Freetown, engaging in petty crime until he met a preacher, Richard Cole, who inspired him to rebuild his life and contribute positively to society. This led him to continue his education and eventually play a significant role during the 2014 Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone. His group educated over 10,000 people about Ebola, supported 11,000 with food and supplies, and established an Ebola treatment unit, significantly impacting the community's response to the outbreak. The passage concludes with his reflections on personal redemption and the importance of investing in youth for a better future. Additionally, the passage notes that the country was recently declared free of a virus that had killed nearly 4,000 people over 18 months.

The Wedgwood Museum's collection of about 80,000 items, including art and ceramics, was at risk of being auctioned to settle the pottery firm's pension debt. A public fundraising campaign successfully raised the necessary funds in a month, ensuring the collection remains at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund, leading the campaign, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then loan it back to the Wedgwood Museum. The collection's preservation was deemed crucial for Staffordshire and significant for Britain's cultural heritage.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal for Mark Wright to buy 20% of Billericay football club are yet to be finalized. Wright, aged 30, is expected to become a club director. Billericay currently ranks eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, trailing by three points for a play-off spot. Mark Wright, who finished second on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, has a history of playing non-league football for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club's new owner, multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, is willing to invest £10,000 weekly. Recently, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky, who is 35 years old.

In a match between Blackpool and Colchester United, the score ended 1-1. Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso assisted Jamille Matt, who scored from close range. Colchester equalized from a corner kick, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring after a goalmouth scramble. Notable events included Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe making crucial saves, including one from George Elokobi and another from Matthew Briggs. Blackpool missed a chance to win when Tom Aldred headed wide from a corner. The game concluded with Colchester's Sean Murray being sent off for a red card offense against Jim McAlister in injury time.

The disused Fawley power station, closed since 2013 after over 40 years of operation, is set to be transformed into the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside. The development will feature a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The iconic 198-meter-high chimney, which has dominated the Solent skyline since the power station was commissioned in 1971, will be retained as a signature piece of infrastructure. The power station, capable of powering one million homes, was sold to developers in 2016, with plans for the new development expected to start construction in 2018 pending outline planning permission.

At the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old Latham won a bronze medal in a race where Adrian Teklinski of Poland took gold and Lucass Liss of Germany secured silver. Latham's success came after a strategic final sprint, having monitored the race and followed Irish rider Felix English. In other events, GB's men's team pursuit was beaten to the bronze by Italy, and Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final. In the women's team pursuit, GB finished fifth and did not advance to the bronze-medal ride. Elinor Barker, an Olympic gold medallist, joined a young squad including Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd, and Ellie Dickinson, who showed promise despite not medaling. Katy Marchant, an Olympic bronze medallist, was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint and is set to compete in two more events.

Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and briefly in 2005-2006, is returning for a brief stint to coincide with the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Peggy returned to Albert Square to reveal her cancer had returned and will die from the disease in upcoming episodes. Kemp's return aims to reunite the Mitchell family, including his on-screen brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden, for Peggy's last scenes, promising emotional and classic episodes. Grant Mitchell, a legendary character in the soap's history, will be back in Walford to say goodbye to his mother and reconnect with past relationships.

Sadio Mane scored twice quickly in a match where second-placed Tottenham Hotspur (Spurs) underperformed against Liverpool at Anfield. Mauricio Pochettino, Spurs' manager, criticized his team's lack of desire and readiness to compete for the Premier League, especially evident in the first half. Spurs have struggled away from home, winning only twice since September 24 and securing just one victory in their last 17 away games against top-six teams. Pochettino expressed concern over Chelsea potentially extending their lead at the top of the league. Former player Danny Murphy noted a surprising defensive lapse by Spurs, who usually excel at home but struggle away, suggesting a tactical error in switching from a back three to a back four formation against strong opponents.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in Nigeria's elections, winning 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking the largest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC's success extended to key northern states and Nigeria's commercial hub, Lagos, although it failed to win in any of the five oil-producing states. The PDP, which had been in power for 16 years, managed to retain control in the south-east and Rivers State, but lost the presidential election to APC's Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on May 29. The elections saw some violence, particularly in the south, but were overall more peaceful than previous years. The PDP's decline was attributed to voter desire for change, defections to the APC, and allegations of corruption and ineffective handling of the Islamist insurgency in the north-east.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from July 19 to 22, features acts like The Waterboys and Imelda May. Attendees can use a new app to access augmented reality content, including videos and band interviews, triggered by festival signs and posters. This feature enhances the festival experience and allows global interaction. The app will provide real-time updates, ticket purchasing, and a taste of the festival's atmosphere to users worldwide.

The passage discusses the Ofsted inspections and subsequent actions taken against several Birmingham academies, including Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School, all rated inadequate. The funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary are set to be terminated, with Park View Educational Trust potentially being removed from running these schools. Oldknow and Golden Hillock were warned of potential funding termination unless they address specified concerns by July 4, including ending discriminatory practices and ensuring a balanced curriculum. The head teacher of one of the affected schools, part of the Trojan Horse scandal, described feeling isolated and nearly quitting due to parental interference and pressure. Ofsted's reports highlighted issues such as inadequate safety measures against extremism and inappropriate external speakers at assemblies. Birmingham City Council plans to work with Saltley School, another affected institution, to improve its governance. Criticism from parents and staff suggests bias in Ofsted's approach, with some calling for a meeting with the Education Secretary to discuss the findings.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 after an eye test at Boots in Ipswich, where eye specialist Honey Rose allegedly failed to detect his swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. This failure, according to the prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court, led to a fatal build-up of fluid in Vinnie's brain. Honey Rose, 35, from Newham, east London, is charged with gross negligence manslaughter, which she denies. The prosecution argues that Vinnie's death was preventable and that Rose's conduct was criminally negligent. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg was convicted of coercing a woman into sexual activities with a man he met through an adult website, which he filmed. He also sent a sexually explicit video to the woman's sister on Christmas Day 2014. Weatherhogg, aged 42, was found guilty after denying the charges at Dundee Sheriff Court. The case was escalated to the High Court in Edinburgh due to its sentencing capabilities. He was placed on the sex offenders register and described as posing a moderate risk of re-offending. The woman felt blackmailed, and the judge emphasized the societal abhorrence of his actions during sentencing.

In a T20 cricket match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5, led by Stuart Thompson's 56, Gary Wilson's unbeaten 41, and William Porterfield's 39. However, Afghanistan chased down the total, reaching 171-4 with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Afghanistan's victory was aided by an opening stand of 51 between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai. Amir Hamza was the standout bowler with figures of 2-23. Ireland's captain, Porterfield, felt they were short of the desired total of 180 and lacked execution with the ball. Ireland also missed paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back injury, though he is expected to return for the upcoming ODIs against Afghanistan starting March 15. The teams are set to play the second T20 at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona insisted they committed no offense regarding the signing of Neymar from Santos for £48.6m, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost to Barcelona, including all fees and payments, amounts to £106.8m. Following accusations of misappropriation, former president Sandro Rosell resigned and is under investigation, though he denies wrongdoing. A Spanish judge found sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer, despite Barcelona's denial of any tax-related crime and their additional tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to cover potential discrepancies in tax obligations. The case's outcome remains uncertain. Neymar has performed well, scoring seven goals in 18 league games and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found murdered on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, have been charged with their murders, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty. They allegedly confessed but later reportedly withdrew their confessions, which Thai police have denied. UK Metropolitan Police officers assisted Thai police in the investigation and have returned to the UK to compile a report and update the families. Concerns were raised by the UK Foreign Office regarding the investigation, particularly about DNA verification and the treatment of the suspects. Post-mortem examinations revealed Miller died from drowning and a head injury, while Witheridge died from head wounds. DNA evidence linked the suspects to Witheridge.

The Scottish women's national football team, led by players like Bayern Munich's forward Evans, is close to qualifying for a major tournament after winning all five of their qualifiers. They are set to host Iceland, ranked just above them at 20th in the world, at Falkirk Stadium. A victory in this match would nearly guarantee Scotland's qualification for the finals in the Netherlands next summer. Both teams are unbeaten, and the outcome of this game and the subsequent match in Reykjavik will likely determine the group winner. Evans, who has played in various top leagues including the Bundesliga, emphasizes the importance of the fans and the advantage of having players with international experience in the squad. She reflects on her recent success with Bayern Munich and the high level of competition in Germany, which she believes benefits the Scottish national team.

The passage discusses Apple's response to the theft of celebrities' intimate photos from iCloud, believed to be facilitated by third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple introduced a two-step verification process as an opt-in security measure to prevent such breaches. This process requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering a username and password on an unfamiliar device. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and related services is denied, though a 14-character recovery key can restore access if the trusted device is lost or stolen. Previously, this security did not apply to iCloud backups, allowing hackers to access data despite two-step verification being enabled. Following the hacks, Apple modified its system to block such unauthorized access to backups and to notify users via email when a backup download begins. Despite these improvements, concerns remain about the security of the recovery key. Experts suggest that two-factor authentication should be a default setting across tech companies, not just an option, to enhance security. Apple plans to encourage users more aggressively to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

In the European election, UKIP, the winner, spent £2,956,737, translating to 68p per vote from their 4,376,635 votes. The Conservatives spent £2,980,815, or 79p per vote. Labour, coming in second, spent £1,027,339, at 26p per vote. The Liberal Democrats, who lost 11 out of 12 MEPs, spent £1,580,575, or £1.45 per vote. The Green Party, fourth place, spent £534,249, at 43p per vote. The SNP spent £267,372. The total campaign spending of the six highest-spending parties was £9,347,087. All parties except Labour increased their spending compared to the 2009 European election campaign. The campaign period was from January 23 to May 22.

Centre-back Anderson, aged 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join a rival National League team, with a possible debut against his former club on February 18. Striker Keating, 21, has joined the Gulls after being recommended by Micky Adams, pending international clearance. Keating previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Anderson is described as a leader with the stature and voice desired by Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson, who also noted Keating's youth and eagerness. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, narrowly beating Thistlecrack. The cause of death was identified as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur in horses without underlying health issues. Despite past incidents of post-race ataxia and overheating, Many Clouds had shown no symptoms on the day of the race. The horse had a successful racing history, including wins in the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup. Trainer Oliver Sherwood praised Many Clouds as the "horse of a lifetime." The British Horseracing Authority is committed to further understanding and preventing such incidents.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was emotional as Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond, both stepping down as MSPs before the election on May 5, gave their farewell speeches in the Scottish Parliament. Alex Salmond, former first minister from 2007 to 2014, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the need for the parliament to take on more governance responsibilities. He welcomed new powers under the Scotland Bill but felt it did not meet referendum campaign promises. Salmond humorously acknowledged competition from the Cheltenham racecourse and wished varying degrees of luck to election candidates. He concluded by highlighting the honor of serving in the parliament and the importance of shaping Scotland's public purpose. Duncan McNeil, serving since 1999, warned of the need for Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, another departing MSP, humorously mentioned missing interactions with John Swinney.

The upcoming live-action film, set to release on March 17, 2017, features Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Kevin Kline will play Belle's father, Maurice, and Josh Gad will portray LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. The star will take on the role of Mrs. Potts, the housekeeper turned teapot, previously voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. Bill Condon will direct the film, which will start filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision on potential charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. The disaster resulted in the deaths of 96 football fans during an FA Cup semi-final. New inquests concluded that the fans were unlawfully killed. The CPS is reviewing evidence against 23 suspects, with 15 linked to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes, and eight connected to a probe into the conduct of South Yorkshire and West Midlands Police post-disaster. Margaret Aspinall, who lost her son in the tragedy and chairs the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed hope that this could mark the end of a long struggle for justice, though she anticipates a continued journey for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced multiple incidents of contraband, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, being thrown over its walls. A local resident observed this happening frequently, and the prison is engaging the community on how to respond to such incidents. A former inmate mentioned the use of drones to deliver contraband directly to prison windows, though the Ministry of Justice denies any drone activity at Chelmsford. The Ministry acknowledges the hard work of staff to prevent contraband entry and notes new laws that could imprison smugglers for up to two years. The Justice Secretary is reviewing additional measures to equip prisons in tackling these issues.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, was seriously injured outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December when Brian Wright, 55, struck her with his VW Golf. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and could not see the red light or Mrs. Blackburn, who was on duty helping a woman and her child cross the road. Wright has admitted to hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denies the charge of causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn, a beloved figure who had served as a lollipop lady for 20 years, is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse in court, stating he has been deeply affected by the incident and apologized to Mrs. Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games next year due to her veterinary medicine studies, which conflict with the event's schedule in April. She recently competed in the World Athletics Championships, finishing fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m, setting a new personal best in the latter with a time of 14:52.07. Despite missing the Commonwealth Games, Muir is targeting the World Indoor Championships in March and is optimistic about her future, mentioning potential participation in at least two or three more Olympics. She expressed disappointment about missing the Commonwealth Games but emphasized the importance of completing her degree.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search began in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations in a three-acre woodland area near the River Liffey, expected to last several weeks. Earlier in the year, a review of his disappearance was conducted by six detectives, who enhanced CCTV footage showing Deely talking to an unidentified man in black outside his workplace on Baggot Street. The footage also captured this man following Deely on Haddington Road. Despite releasing the footage and appealing for information, the man has not been identified, and gardaí renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Del Potro, ranked 165th after a two-year injury hiatus, defeated Swiss player Stan Wawrinka with a score of 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 in a Grand Slam match, marking his return since the 2014 Australian Open. The 27-year-old Argentine, a former US Open champion and world number four, expressed joy and relief at his victory and the support from the crowd. In the same tournament, Australia's Nick Kyrgios, ranked 15th, overcame a challenging match against Germany's Dustin Brown, winning 6-7 (3-7), 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4 after multiple rain delays. Kyrgios is set to face Spain's 22nd seed Feliciano Lopez in the third round, with a potential match against Andy Murray in the last 16. Lopez had previously come back from two sets down to beat Fabio Fognini. Other notable results include victories by 10th seed Tomas Berdych and 12th seed Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.
