As of March 13th, over 145,000 COVID-19 cases were confirmed across more than 130 countries, with significant outbreaks in China, Italy, South Korea, and Iran.
As of March 13th, over 145,000 COVID-19 cases were confirmed across 140 countries, with significant outbreaks in China, Italy, South Korea, and Iran.
Between 29 and 52 Muslims were killed and over 100 were wounded in an incident involving gunman Goldstein, leading to continued riots in Hebron.
In the passage, 29 Muslims were killed and over 100 were wounded. The incident is linked to settlers remembering gunman Goldstein and ongoing riots in Hebron.
By March 26, over 21,300 deaths were attributed to COVID-19.
By March 27, over 26,300 deaths were attributed to COVID-19.
By 28 March, at least 5,138 people had died from COVID-19, 4,165 were in intensive care with 1,312 of those in Madrid, and over 350,000 tests had been conducted.

By 28 March, the reported data indicated at least 5,812 deaths due to COVID-19, with 4,165 individuals hospitalized in intensive care, including 1,312 in the Community of Madrid. Over 350,000 tests for the virus had been conducted.
By 29 February, Italy had conducted over 18,500 tests for the virus.
By March 1, Italy had conducted 21,127 tests for the virus.

Qatar Airways, based in the Qatar Airways Tower in Doha, operates a hub-and-spoke network from Hamad International Airport. It connects over 160 international destinations across multiple continents using a fleet of over 200 aircraft.

Qatar Airways, based in the Qatar Airways Tower in Doha, operates a hub-and-spoke network from Hamad International Airport. It connects over 150 international destinations across multiple continents including Africa, Central Asia, Europe, the Far East, South Asia, the Middle East, North America, South America, and Oceania, with a fleet exceeding 200 aircraft.
Maxthon is the second most popular browser in China and has been downloaded over 400 million times globally.
Maxthon is the second most popular browser in China and has been downloaded over 500 million times globally.
More than 16,700 people have died and over 102,000 have recovered from a global issue that has affected more individuals than reported.
The passage reports that worldwide, there have been over 392,000 cases of a certain condition, resulting in more than 17,100 deaths and over 102,000 recoveries.

Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend after Townsend was substituted into a Tottenham match against Burnley with only seven minutes left, resulting in a 0-0 draw. Merson mocked Townsend on Twitter, referencing their previous conflict which stemmed from Merson's criticism of Townsend's inclusion in the England squad. Despite Merson's earlier doubts, Townsend scored a stunning equalizer for England against Italy, prompting Merson to admit his mistake and express genuine pleasure for Townsend's success. However, any reconciliation was short-lived as Merson took another jab at Townsend following the Burnley match.

Chelsea have made an offer for 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, as confirmed by FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. If Muto moves to Chelsea, he will be loaned to Vitesse Arnhem next season. Muto, who recently graduated with an economics degree from Keio University, has played 37 games for FC Tokyo, scoring 16 goals, and has 11 caps for Japan with one international goal. Despite the offer, Muto has not yet decided on joining Chelsea, though he considers it an honor. The interest in Muto is unrelated to Chelsea's £200million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The Finnish research, involving over 12,000 children, showed that by age two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese, with those given antibiotics, especially repeatedly, being at higher risk. The study suggests that antibiotics might contribute to the childhood obesity epidemic by altering gut bacteria, which could increase food availability and appetite. The findings highlight the need for cautious use of antibiotics in infancy due to their potential role in the global obesity issue, particularly affecting boys more than girls.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, an event witnessed by hundreds of tourists and captured on camera by holidaymaker David Meadwell. The young guard, part of the Queen's Guard, lost his footing, slid sideways, hit his bearskin on the sentry box, and dropped his rifle. Despite quickly getting up, the guard was visibly embarrassed as his colleagues continued the ceremony unaffected. The incident, attributed to metal protectors on his boots, occurred last week and was recorded outside Buckingham Palace.

The miniseries "Roots," originally aired in 1977 with over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E networks for a 2016 release. The new version will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History, focusing on the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in Virginia. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce this updated series, which aims to be more authentic by drawing directly from Alex Haley's novel and consulting with scholars. The remake seeks to resonate with both fans of the original and a new generation, amidst recent historical and cultural milestones like the presidency of Barack Obama and the film "12 Years a Slave."

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, claims he was subjected to an attempted orgy by palace aides on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978. The 27-year-old was allegedly groped and pinned to a chair after entering a bedroom to find a pen. He left the job immediately after the incident. After hearing about investigations into historical child sex abuse cases last year, Lawler contacted palace officials but was initially ignored. His complaint was eventually passed to the police, who are now investigating. A retired royal aide denied involvement, claiming to have been at Balmoral at the time. The Royal Household has pledged full cooperation with the police investigation.

Jesse and Melissa Meek, an Oregon couple, announced their pregnancy through a rap video parody set to the theme song of the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood while driving. In the video, Melissa shares her realization of being pregnant and the couple reveals a sonogram at the end. The video took five takes to film and was made to share the news with distant loved ones. Unexpectedly, the video became very popular, exceeding the couple's expectations. They are considering making another video after learning the baby's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills. The gray jacket and full skirt, originally slate blue-gray but faded over time, was featured in several key scenes including encounters with Rhett Butler and an attack in shanty town. The auction included over 150 items from the film, part of James Tumblin's collection, who acquired the dress for $20 from the Western Costume Company. Other notable auction items included a straw hat worn by Leigh, a suit worn by Clark Gable, and a bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland. "Gone With the Wind," celebrating its 75th anniversary, is based on Margaret Mitchell's novel and features Hattie McDaniel, who became the first African-American to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after being dangled over the edge by his parents. The incident occurred around 3pm on a Saturday when the toddler slipped from his mother's arms, falling 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The parents rescued the child before emergency services arrived. The boy sustained minor injuries, including bumps, bruises, and a leg injury, but was not attacked by the cheetahs, who did not approach him or his parents. He was treated at MetroHealth Medical Center and listed in stable condition. Eyewitnesses reported shock at the incident, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The cheetah exhibit was closed following the event.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, originally used to enforce a 30mph speed limit, has been non-functional for over two years since all fixed speed cameras in the West Midlands were turned off in March 2013. The camera, which has been re-angled to point at a house on Wellington Road, prompted action from Birmingham City Council after they were made aware of the situation. The council plans to send an engineer to assess and possibly remove the camera. The region now uses mobile camera units, fixed motorway cameras, and traffic officers for speed enforcement. The council is developing a pilot program with new digital technology at select sites, but the Wellington Road camera will not be part of this initiative.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt expressed his readiness and enthusiasm for the event, highlighting Jamaica's successful relay tradition and his commitment to making his country proud. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association's General Secretary, Garth Gayle, is pleased with Bolt's participation, anticipating exceptional performances at the relays.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates at Barcelona, showed support for the club's basketball team by attending El Clasico, where Barcelona narrowly defeated Real Madrid 85-80 in the Euro League. Despite the win, Real Madrid leads their division due to a better points difference. Neymar, who recently captained Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile amidst rough play, was accompanied by his sister Rafaella at the basketball game. Before the international break, Barcelona, led by Luis Enrique, won their soccer El Clasico against Real Madrid, extending their lead at the top of La Liga by four points. Barcelona is set to face Celta Vigo next in their pursuit of a treble.

Italy is experiencing an increase in migrant arrivals from Africa and the Middle East, with 8,480 migrants rescued over a recent four-day period. The Italian coast guard has been actively involved in these rescues, responding to numerous SOS calls. There are unconfirmed reports of a boat carrying 550 migrants capsizing, with fears that 400 could be missing, though no evidence has been found to support this incident. In the first three months of 2015, over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy, with many coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died this year during the crossing, primarily due to bad weather and overcrowded boats often abandoned by smugglers.

Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over other clubs, including Liverpool, after leaving Barcelona, and has made a significant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals in his first season. Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased with Sanchez's decision and performance, highlighting his quick adaptation and valuable contributions to the team. Wenger also acknowledged Liverpool's interest in Sanchez might have been used as leverage in negotiations over Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona. Additionally, Wenger dismissed rumors about a potential transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and praised Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for managing well post-Suarez and despite injuries.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record of 52.491km is held by Australian Rohan Dennis, set in February after UCI's regulation changes. Wiggins, who recently concluded his Team Sky career at Paris-Roubaix, aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes at the Lee Valley VeloPark. He hopes to inspire others and perform in front of a full 6,000-capacity crowd, with tickets available from April 19. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Before this, Wiggins will participate in the Tour de Yorkshire and is targeting an eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics in the team pursuit.

Serena Williams, despite being the world No 1, found her match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup play-off challenging, describing it as an 'eye-opener' as she prepares for the claycourt season. Williams eventually won 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, maintaining her 8-0 record against Errani, but admitted she was not as ready for clay as she thought. The US team, including Williams and Alison Riske, lost the doubles match 6-0, 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in a 3-2 defeat and relegation to World Group II. Tough weather conditions affected the match, and Williams noted the need to adapt her game for clay. Despite her recent success, including her 19th singles grand slam at the Australian Open, the French Open remains her least successful major. The US team, led by captain Mary Joe Fernandez, aims to work harder and return to the World Group next year.

River Plate is interested in re-signing their former striker Radamel Falcao, who is currently on loan at Manchester United from Monaco. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the club's desire to bring back Falcao, stating that "the doors are open" for him. Falcao, who has struggled at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals this season, previously played for River Plate from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. Despite his challenges at United, Falcao has recently performed well for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games and tying the country's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, known for her vocals on The X Factor in 2012, has become the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration at age 19. The campaign, launched with a TV ad featuring her song "Mirror Man," showcases Henderson in various hairstyles against a vibrant city backdrop. She is seen in different outfits, including a black blouse with a leather jacket and a maxi dress with animal-print sheer panels. The partnership, facilitated by MILES agency, aligns the platinum award-winning artist with the UK's top dry shampoo brand, Batiste, which Henderson uses regularly. Mark Hargreaves from Crown Talent & Media Group praised the natural synergy between Henderson and Batiste, anticipating an exciting 2015.

Aaron Siler, 26, was fatally shot by police officer Pablo Torres on March 14 in Kenosha, Wisconsin, after Siler armed himself during a confrontation following a vehicle and foot pursuit. Siler was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant. In the aftermath, a billboard featuring Torres and his dog, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, was erected to thank the community for its support. This billboard has caused shock and outrage among Siler's family and friends, who find it disrespectful and are demanding its removal. The police association stated that no offense was intended, emphasizing the community's support during recent incidents. Torres is currently on leave as the investigation into Siler's shooting continues. Additionally, Torres had shot another individual, Terry Knight, just 10 days prior, an incident deemed justified by the District Attorney.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants from the Jaish al Adal group near the Pakistan border in the town of Negur. Three militants were also killed by Iranian forces. The militants, who crossed into Iran from Pakistan, are part of a Sunni Muslim group opposing Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian officials have requested Pakistani authorities to capture the surviving militants. Jaish al Adal, active in Pakistan's Balochistan province, has previously claimed responsibility for attacks on Iranian soil, including a deadly 2013 incident. Pakistan condemned the attack, is investigating, and has promised to apprehend the militants if they return to Pakistan.

The passage discusses a political inquiry in Japan about UFOs, initiated by former wrestler and lawmaker Antonio Inoki. In response to Inoki's question in Japan's parliament, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that Japan's Air Self Defense Force had never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs, though they do investigate unidentified flying objects that could threaten Japan's airspace. Inoki, known for his diverse career in wrestling, politics, and entertainment, has a history of notable actions including fighting Muhammad Ali, attempting hostage negotiations in Iraq, and promoting various products. He also claims to have seen a UFO himself but remains uncertain about the existence of aliens. The discussion reflects ongoing interest in extraterrestrial topics among Japanese politicians, referencing a similar discussion in 2007 by then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba about the legal implications of defending against an alien invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

Jin Pai, a 35-year-old passenger at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, Anhui Province, China, was hospitalized after a toilet he was standing on to avoid touching what he thought was an unclean seat broke beneath him. The incident resulted in deep cuts to his leg and buttocks, requiring numerous stitches. Initially, Jin told friends he was squatting, but later claimed to police he was sitting when the toilet collapsed, possibly to avoid compensation costs. Authorities treated the incident as an accident and advised that toilets are designed for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for sexually abusing a girl over four years and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The abuse started when the victim was nine and continued until she was 13. The hidden camera, discovered by the now 15-year-old victim, captured 41 videos over three to four years, including footage of the girl and others showering. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault and invasion of privacy. He admitted to filming multiple victims and had specifically purchased the camera to record the victim. Rebbie is held on $500,000 bail with a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's series features fathers in suits leaping energetically next to their casually dressed daughters, who remain po-faced or smiling. The images, part of Aoyama's book titled "Daughter and Salary Man," showcase fathers expressing a fun, heroic side through dramatic poses, some of which appear pained, especially among older fathers. The photos, set against various Japanese landmarks, have sparked significant online interest despite little known background information.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has shifted focus to the start of the county championship season, with particular attention on Kevin Pietersen. Pietersen, who was controversially dropped by Downton in 2014, is attempting to return to the England team through his performances with Surrey. He displayed a range of emotions during a team photo shoot at the KIA Oval, appearing deep in thought yet jovial as he interacted with photographers and teammates. Surrey is set to begin their campaign against Glamorgan on April 19, with Pietersen hoping to help England regain the Ashes on home soil this summer.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian football club facing relegation, sacked their Brazilian coach Ze Maria twice within a week. Initially fired on Wednesday due to poor performance, Ze Maria was reinstated the following day by the club's owner, Angelo Massone. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, Ze Maria was sacked again. The former Brazil defender, who had 25 caps for his country, was replaced by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic. Ceahlaul are currently 16th in the league standings, six points from safety.

Radamel Falcao, on loan from Monaco to Manchester United, has struggled to perform as he did before a serious knee injury, scoring only four goals in the season. His former teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets the move to United, suggesting he would have been better off staying at Monaco where he could have played in the Champions League, despite not being happy there. Manchester United is unlikely to pay the £46 million required to make Falcao's transfer permanent.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday. The robber, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt, stole the dairy's till containing about $1500 after demanding cash from the owner's 30-year-old daughter. The incident occurred around 12:30 pm at the Union St dairy in east Christchurch. No weapons were reported, but the robber remains at large. The police are urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice within a month for inappropriate relationships with underage students. Initially arrested on March 19, she admitted to kissing a 15-year-old student and allowing him to touch her breasts the previous April, leading to her suspension and administrative leave. Subsequently, on Monday, she was arrested again after another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. Granado was released on a $50,000 bail following her second arrest. The Irving school district confirmed taking immediate action and stated that her administrative leave prevents her from working with students or being on school property.

A video capturing a crocodile swimming in a Puerto Vallarta marina with a dead dog in its jaws has garnered over half a million views online. The dog, belonging to a local bike shop owner, was killed after approaching the water's edge out of curiosity near a crocodile sanctuary. New Zealander Tim Weston, who witnessed the event while on holiday, noted the crocodile held the dog in its mouth for hours. The incident, which occurred in a tourist area known for its proximity to crocodile habitats, has sparked strong reactions on social media, with some viewers expressing horror and disdain towards crocodiles.

Steve Bruce remains confident in keeping Hull City in the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, which has left them two points above the relegation zone with six games remaining. Hull aimed for 10 wins to stay up but have only achieved six, with Bruce now hoping eight or nine might suffice. The team showed promise in the first half against Southampton but conceded from a James Ward-Prowse penalty and a late goal by Graziano Pelle. Upcoming challenging matches include Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes Hull's struggles to long-term injuries to key players like Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Meanwhile, Southampton's victory moved them to fifth in the league, though their manager Ronald Koeman had to address a penalty-taking dispute involving Sadio Mane and Ward-Prowse.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from teaching for at least two years after he allowed and assisted pupils in altering their SATs exam answers post-exam session. This misconduct led to the annulment of the entire school's SATs results for 2014 by the Department for Education. Guffick admitted to the allegations, claiming he intended to make answers more legible, not to change them. However, a panel from the National College for Teaching and Leadership ruled that any changes outside test conditions were unacceptable. Despite Guffick's remorse and the panel's acknowledgment of his pressure to achieve good results, his actions were deemed deliberate and serious, resulting in his prohibition from the classroom.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year. The couple, who have been dating since 2012 and have a son together, enjoyed some time off in the English sunshine. Lindegaard, who has struggled for playing time at Manchester United since joining in 2010, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons, is currently third-choice goalkeeper behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite his limited success on the pitch, Lindegaard frequently shares his life with Beqiri on Instagram, where she also posts her modeling work and has over 17,000 followers.

The glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium, which were installed in 1976 and removed in 2008, failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction despite expectations of fetching between $300,000 and $600,000. Owned by Reggie Jackson, who bought them after the stadium's last game, the 10-feet-tall letters received no bids beyond a Sotheby's employee's attempt to start the bidding at $260,000. Jackson, hoping a new generation would enjoy this New York icon, had purchased the letters impulsively. Meanwhile, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed the recent off-field behavior of Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, who were seen inhaling nitrous oxide and smoking shisha pipes. Despite the incidents, Rodgers chose not to discipline the players but instead used the opportunity to remind them of their professional responsibilities. This comes ahead of Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, where Sterling will lead the line due to Daniel Sturridge's injury. Rodgers also has Steven Gerrard available after a suspension, though he did not confirm if Gerrard would start. Rodgers emphasized learning from setbacks, referencing Liverpool's near successes in previous competitions, and expressed his focus on guiding the team to their first FA Cup final under his management.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after the international break and shared a picture on Twitter of himself relaxing with his dog, captioning it "Home Sweet Home." During the break, Ozil played a key role in Germany's 2-0 victory over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. He missed Arsenal's previous match against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to play in the upcoming Premier League game against Liverpool. Since recovering from an injury, Ozil has been in excellent form, contributing four assists and scoring three goals since January. He also commented on adjusting well to the demands of English football, expressing his preference for the frequent matches.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has expressed satisfaction with manager Luis Enrique, stating that the club has no plans to replace him despite rumors. Enrique, who took over last summer on a two-year deal, is close to securing the La Liga title, being only six games away. Bartomeu praised Enrique's dedication, especially noting his preparation for matches, including a recent game against Valencia which Barcelona won with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi. Enrique's contract runs until 2016, and Barcelona is still in contention for three trophies as the season concludes.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract worth around £100,000-a-week, extending his stay at the club until 2020. With 14 months left on his previous deal, negotiations had been ongoing since the start of the season. Henderson, who joined from Sunderland in 2011 for £16 million, has shown significant improvement under manager Brendan Rodgers, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season. He is the third key player after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho to extend his contract. Henderson is a potential candidate to replace Steven Gerrard as captain when Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy. Meanwhile, talks with Raheem Sterling are postponed until the end of the season, despite his rejection of a new deal, and Liverpool anticipates retaining him long-term.

Filipe Luis, a Chelsea full back, has expressed his desire to remain with the club until his contract ends, despite interest from his former team, Atletico Madrid. He signed a three-year deal with Chelsea last July but has not secured the left back position. Amidst the Premier League title race, Luis emphasized the importance of focus and winning every game, as instructed by Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho. Luis recently played for Brazil in friendly matches against France and Chile.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North overturned on appeal. Initially suspended for being 'reckless' when his knee collided with North's head during a try-scoring incident on March 27, Hughes was shown a red card and missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final. Despite no intent being acknowledged, the original sanction was lifted following widespread criticism and an appeal upheld by Wasps. George North, knocked unconscious for the third time in two months, was advised to take at least a month off due to concussion. Hughes is now free to play but will not feature in Wasps' next match, with his likely return set for April 26 against Exeter.

A fiery sunset observed in Washington was photographed by Seattle native Tim Durkan and shared on CNN iReport. The vivid red color of the sunset was caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia, started by farmers and exacerbated by strong winds on April 14. The smoke traveled across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors, leaving red and orange hues more visible, especially during sunsets and sunrises. As the smoke dissipates, air quality is expected to improve and the intensity of the red sunsets will diminish.

Becky Schoenig's 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway in St. Louis, Missouri, shortly after she purchased it. The car was later recovered by police following a tip from Mick Sexton, who recognized the vehicle. When returned, the car had been modified with red spray-painted rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her car. However, she plans to have it professionally cleaned due to the lingering smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Additionally, Schoenig, who owns The Hot Pot restaurant, is creating a smoothie named "Sexton on Wheels" in honor of Mick Sexton, featuring banana, pineapple, peach, and coconut cream. Her friend Marlene Trice described her as vibrant, happy, and someone who loves making people laugh.

Manchester City players, including stars like Sergio Aguero and Yaya Toure, stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League. The team, managed by Manuel Pellegrini, is currently in fourth place in the Premier League, with their European hopes hanging in the balance after a loss to rivals Manchester United in the Manchester derby. The squad's incentivised contracts are designed to comply with financial fairplay rules, and collectively, they have £12 million at stake. City's season has been disappointing, with seven losses since the start of 2015, including early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League. Their upcoming matches include games against West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, Queens Park Rangers, Swansea, and Southampton. Meanwhile, Manchester United, led by Louis van Gaal, are four points ahead of City and are confident in attracting top talent in the next transfer window.

Manchester United's Under 18 team defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' match at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal from a free-kick. The game, which attracted nearly 1,000 spectators and was free to enter, showcased a high number of English and local Mancunian players. United lined up in a formation similar to their first team, while City's Marcus Wood and United's Marcus Rashford had notable moments. The result keeps United close to the top of the Barclays Under 18s Premier League, two points behind Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City has lost both their playoff matches.

Joe Hart, the England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap for Italy during a 1-1 draw with England. Hart, who celebrated his 50th cap for England in the same match, expressed admiration for Buffon, highlighting his inspiration and longevity in the sport at age 37. Hart, at 27, aims to continue improving and increasing his own cap count, expressing pride in his achievements so far and his desire to keep playing well for both club and country.

Chipotle has entered the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app, offering delivery in 67 cities with a nine percent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. This move comes after Chipotle previously declined offers from other third-party delivery services. Alongside this new venture, Chipotle has been frequented by presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton. Other fast-food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also expanding into the delivery market.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, have publicly urged the Justice Department to forgo the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges related to the bombings. In a Boston Globe opinion piece, Bill and Denise Richard detailed the severe impact of their son's death and their daughter Jane's injuries on their family. They expressed support for Tsarnaev to spend life in prison without parole and waive his appeal rights, arguing that pursuing the death penalty would lead to prolonged appeals and further pain for their family. The Richards emphasized their personal stance against the death penalty, hoping to move forward and heal, without mentioning Tsarnaev by name.

A Boeing 747 has been transformed into a luxurious private home for a billionaire, costing £400 million. The customized jet, which typically seats 600 passengers, now accommodates the owner and dozens of guests with amenities including multiple lounges, bedrooms, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a conference room, and an 'aeroloft' with eight beds. The interior, designed by Greenpoint Technologies, features a hotel-like ambiance with various rooms for relaxation, work, and entertainment, far surpassing the luxury of first-class commercial flights.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket with an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Florida, aimed at resupplying the International Space Station. The Dragon is carrying over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker. The mission marks SpaceX's sixth to the ISS and the second attempt after a weather-related delay. While the Dragon successfully headed towards the ISS, the attempt to land the Falcon 9's first stage on a floating barge failed as the rocket landed too hard and tipped over. SpaceX aims to reuse rockets to significantly reduce space travel costs. After delivering its cargo, the Dragon will return to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of materials, splashing down in the Pacific Ocean.

Priscilla Presley, aged 69, will witness the first wedding at the newly opened Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, located at the Westgate Hotel. The chapel, part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, was launched through a contest by NBC's Today show, offering an 'ultimate wedding' package. The winning couple, to be announced the following Monday, will marry on April 23 and receive a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel stay, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience show. Priscilla emphasized the chapel's first-class nature, banning impersonators and underscoring its seriousness. Couples had to submit videos or photos explaining their eligibility for the contest.

Jordan Henderson believes Liverpool can catch Manchester City in the Premier League, despite being four points behind. Both Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season in a 2-0 victory over Newcastle United, equalling a record for appearances in top European leagues. Liverpool regained winning form after disappointing results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scored in the match against Newcastle, with Allen's goal being his first at Anfield. Despite a potential penalty not given to Newcastle, Liverpool secured a crucial win in their pursuit of a Champions League spot.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. The game, held on Saturday, saw Roma take the lead in the 25th minute through a goal by Miralem Pjanic following a swift counter-attack. Roma's goalkeeper, Morgan de Sanctis, played a pivotal role in securing the victory by making crucial saves in the second half. This win moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of their city rivals, Lazio. Meanwhile, Napoli extended their winless streak to five matches, remaining in fifth place. The match was also notable for heightened security measures due to past incidents between the two clubs' fans.

Doncaster Rovers had a lackluster season, remaining mid-table in League One. Their match against Fleetwood Town, a team with faded playoff hopes, resulted in a goalless draw at the Keepmoat Stadium. The game, which tested fans' patience, was so uneventful that Doncaster's media team struggled to compile match highlights, ultimately posting a brief 27-second video on YouTube, featuring only 14 seconds of actual gameplay.

The passage describes the unique bond between Roland Giroux and his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan around 1986. Unlike typical marine pets, this fish interacts closely with Giroux, allowing him to stroke and massage it inside its tank. The fish, initially sharing its tank with two others, was later isolated due to bullying. Giroux feeds it by hand and spends at least 15 minutes daily playing with it, noting the fish's enjoyment and even frustration if not interacted with regularly. The interaction includes the fish swimming around Giroux's hand and arm, and returning for more strokes after brief swims away.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character in the England cricket team, returned to the Kensington Oval where he previously broke his wrist punching a locker. This incident serves as a reminder for him to channel his aggression appropriately. Despite a minor back issue, Stokes has fought back into the team after a challenging year. His confrontational nature was evident in clashes, such as with Marlon Samuels and during the Ashes against Mitchell Johnson, but he has shown positive responses after guidance from coach Peter Moores. England values Stokes' natural exuberance and aggression, which they believe can contribute to runs and wickets, but stress the importance of controlling it to avoid being pigeon-holed. The team aims to support Stokes and Chris Jordan to reach their full potential, preferring to include both in the lineup over a second spinner like Adil Rashid, especially as the need for two spinners is less likely in upcoming matches.

The Euro 2016 qualifier match between Wales and Belgium, set to take place at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12, has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams are leading Group B with 11 points each, but Belgium is ahead due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 win against Israel has boosted expectations for their qualification to the 2016 finals in France. The match could not be moved to the larger Millennium Stadium due to UEFA rules, and the Wales team prefers playing at the Cardiff City Stadium.

John Peacock has announced England's squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where they will defend their title won against Holland last year. England, who qualified with a perfect record, are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. They will start their campaign against Italy on May 7 in Burgas, followed by matches against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. The squad includes promising talents from various Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, the latter receiving his first call-up. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return to the team after missing the Elite Round qualifiers, where England defeated Romania, Norway, and Slovenia.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, considered one of the best talents from Anderlecht's youth academy. He has also attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona, though he previously declined an offer from Barcelona's La Masia to focus on his studies. Manchester City has engaged in talks with Anderlecht's chairman to negotiate a compensation package for Patoulidis, as part of manager Manuel Pellegrini's strategy to build for the future.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found dead in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. She had been strangled and beaten, with fatal injuries to her head and neck. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death and has been released on bail, required to return for further questioning. Santillan, a Mexican national, worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami. The police are appealing for anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death to come forward, as they continue their investigation led by Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves.

Dawn, who suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show to confront her friend Jamie, a convicted burglar, about stealing £207 intended for her baby Daniel James's gravestone. The money was part of the £500 needed for the headstone. A lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt, revealing he had taken the money and blamed his girlfriend Carol. Devastated, Dawn expressed her betrayal and grief over the incident, emphasizing her emotional attachment to the gravestone as a final gesture of love for her son.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, primarily women and children, along with some ill or elderly individuals, on Wednesday. The release was facilitated by Arab tribal leaders, though the exact motivation remains unclear. The freed Yazidis were received by the Peshmerga and taken to Irbil, the capital of Iraq's Kurdish region. Reports on the number of released Yazidis vary, with counts of 217 and 228 mentioned. ISIS had previously released other Yazidis since their attacks began last summer. The Yazidis, a minority group of Kurdish descent practicing a pre-Islamic religion, have faced severe persecution from ISIS, including mass killings, enslavement, and rape, particularly following the conquest of Sinjar which led to a significant humanitarian crisis. International response included airdrops, rescues, and airstrikes by the U.S. and other nations starting in August.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham and England striker, has had an outstanding season, highlighted by his nomination for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. His performances include scoring his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle and notable goals against Chelsea and Arsenal. Additionally, Kane features in a new animation by Copa90, which showcases his best goals and celebrations from the season, released ahead of the awards ceremony where he competes against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers continuing as Liverpool's manager despite a third consecutive season without a trophy and a probable finish outside the top four. Carragher believes Rodgers should not be judged solely on one game and remains optimistic about the team's future, suggesting that with the right signings, Liverpool could improve and compete for trophies and a top-four spot next season. Additionally, Carragher was honored with a Beacon Award for his community work in Merseyside, where he has been actively involved in coaching and supporting youth in underprivileged areas through his 23 Foundation.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic nerf gun, which fires sponge darts, confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to security concerns. The toy was detected by X-ray machines, leading to a thorough pat-down of James by security staff, whom his father, Phil Hayward, described as 'over-zealous'. The family was en route to a 10-day holiday in Lanzarote over Easter. Despite the inconvenience, they could not argue due to time constraints and left the toy behind. Upon returning, James was bought a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized but justified their actions citing government regulations that prohibit items resembling prohibited items, such as replica or model guns, through security.

A man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He detailed his requirements for the ideal partner, including being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit and attractive, good with pets, reliable, honest, loyal, skilled around the house, a good cook, and great in bed. Rich offered accommodation, a potential company car, phone, laptop, and a free gym membership to the successful applicant. He described himself as a 31-year-old, athletic, heavily tattooed, financially successful property owner who enjoys the outdoors, sports, and traveling. Rich emphasized that he is willing to spend generously on his partner and promised to consider all reasonable offers, though former partners are not eligible to apply.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is supported by five former England managers in his effort to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to twelve. The proposal also redefines 'home-grown' to mean training in England for three years before age 18. This initiative faces opposition from the Premier League. The former managers, including Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren, warn that rejecting these changes could hinder England's football progress and chances of winning the World Cup. They emphasize the shrinking pool of English talent at top levels and stress the importance of providing opportunities to emerging young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane.

In the latest episode of the show, Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, gives birth to a baby daughter after a rapid pregnancy timeline that jumps from the announcement to eight months pregnant within episodes. Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner, expresses deep affection for Demelza, indicating his heart is committed to her despite his popularity among female viewers. The show's handling of pregnancy timelines has been noted by fans on social media for its accelerated pace, similar to a previous instance with another character, Elizabeth.

Leicester City, managed by Nigel Pearson, are three points from safety in the Premier League after securing back-to-back wins, including a 3-2 victory over West Brom with an injury-time goal by Jamie Vardy. Despite their position at the bottom of the table, Pearson emphasizes the importance of focusing on their own performance rather than their relegation rivals as they approach the end of the season. He warns against over-optimism and stresses that their future remains in their own hands if they concentrate on their upcoming games.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara set a record for the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's trip included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she might be from the eastern population rather than the endangered western gray whales. This finding could impact the estimated number of western gray whales and indicates a need for further genetic study.

A 1,000 to 1,640ft long and 100ft wide section of seabed emerged overnight along the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu on Hokkaido Island, Japan, rising up to 50ft above sea level. This unexpected event, caused by a nearby landslide triggered by melting ice and snow, surprised local residents who reported no sounds or tremors. Geologists and local researchers confirmed the land swell through aerial surveys, and authorities do not expect further expansion. The emergence is unrelated to a recent earthquake in Kathmandu and marine life remains attached to the new landmass.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain, expressing his love for the club, the city, and his teammates. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped for a Champions League match, Van der Wiel insists he is happy at PSG and wants to sign a new contract. However, the club's interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves might affect Van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez, currently with Juventus, has expressed his desire to leave the club this summer to return to his former club, Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite his contract with Juventus running until the end of the next season, Tevez has reportedly informed the club of his wish to depart. Boca Juniors are close to finalizing his return, but it is contingent on Tevez terminating his contract with Juventus first. Tevez, who has been a key player for Juventus, scoring 17 goals this season and on track to win a second Serie A title, has shocked the club with his decision. Juventus, while reluctant, has started looking for his replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, supports Tevez's decision, stating it will not affect his future with the Argentina national team.

During a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1, securing their spot in the semi-finals. Bayern's manager, Pep Guardiola, experienced a wardrobe malfunction, tearing a hole in his left trouser leg during the excitement of the game, which led to his underwear being visible. Goals were scored by Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski, who scored twice. Despite Porto's initial two-goal lead from their previous match, Bayern's performance was dominant, showcasing their superiority over a stunned Porto team.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, affecting ten people, including four children. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were initially airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital with chest injuries. Subsequently, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain were also airlifted. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment. One person was trapped and freed using hydraulic cutting gear by Queensland Fire and Rescue. The highway was closed with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

This weekend, Arsenal, currently second in the Premier League, will face league leaders Chelsea. Arsenal's midfielder Mesut Ozil is eagerly awaiting the match, having recently purchased an Apple Watch, which he showcased on Instagram, likening it to Michael Knight's watch from the TV show Knight Rider. The Apple Watch, priced between £299 and £13,500, will be available for general sale starting Friday. Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is expected to play in the upcoming game at the Emirates Stadium. Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six games left in the season. The team has been bolstered by the return of Jack Wilshere, who was on the bench during their FA Cup semi-final win against Reading. Former Arsenal player Ray Parlour praised Wilshere's potential but expressed concerns about his fitness, citing Wilshere's injury history as a significant barrier to his development and consistency.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby at Old Trafford between Manchester United and Manchester City. Despite sending off three players from both teams this season, including City's captain Vincent Kompany during an international match, Clattenburg has only issued two red cards in the Premier League, both to United players Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw. The match is crucial as United, riding a five-game winning streak, are just a point ahead of City, who have struggled recently. Clattenburg, considered one of the Premier League's top referees, will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Bob Katter, a federal MP of Lebanese descent, accused the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as a 'little black puppet on a string', suggesting they believed he would resign after being accused of domestic violence and revealing his criminal past. Gordon, who was forced to leave the Queensland Labor Party, chose to remain in parliament as an independent, causing instability in the government due to its slim majority. Katter's statement drew criticism on social media for his choice of words, though he defended his use of the term 'black puppet', citing personal experiences with racism and his intention to highlight racial overtones in the government's expectations of Gordon. Katter also referenced federal MPs Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott as examples of independents who became government puppets, but expressed confidence that Gordon would maintain his independence.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, uses dance videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Facing bullying and stares due to her disability, she aims to change how people with disabilities are viewed in media and society. Through her videos, including one set to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," Dayna emphasizes her similarities to others despite doing things differently. She has also started motivational speaking at local schools, turning negativity into positivity and encouraging people not to judge based on disability.

Orlando City, an MLS team, has shown interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez, a Mexico international, would attract significant commercial interest due to Orlando's large Latin-American fanbase. The club, led by coach Adrian Heath and captained by Kaka, made inquiries about Hernandez last week. Despite interest from eight European clubs including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, Hernandez could be sold by Manchester United for around £8 million as he has one year left on his contract. Meanwhile, Manchester United have offered a revised contract to their 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting United's initial offer. Pereira was an unused substitute in a recent match against Aston Villa.

A group of at least three individuals attacked a man at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am on Saturday. After an argument, they attempted to carjack him, poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger, and set it on fire while two passengers were inside. No one was injured, but the car was completely destroyed. The incident is being investigated as an arson by the Los Angeles County Fire Department, with the suspects still at large and surveillance video being utilized in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. He agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before resuming practice. Despite these actions, Manuel received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com. His practice was listed at a residential address in Lamoni.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker over the Baltic Sea in international airspace, an action the U.S. described as "unsafe and unprofessional" due to the Russian jet's aggressive maneuvers and high speed. The incident prompted the U.S. to file a complaint with Russia through diplomatic channels. Russia claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward their border with its transponder off, a claim the U.S. denied. This is not the first such incident, as a similar encounter occurred a year prior over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains inside a truck safe, was stolen from a car parked at the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City. The theft occurred overnight on March 27, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The thief broke the rear right passenger-side window, used a rope to pull the rifle case out, damaging the car's window frame in the process. Additional items stolen included a gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools. Some of the agent's belongings were later found at a nearby Residence Inn, but the sniper rifle remains missing. The hotel, located near the city's airport and the state's FBI office, lacks surveillance cameras. The rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, and the Secret Service was notified prior to Obama's visit, though it's unclear if security measures were heightened as a result. Police are unsure if the agent's car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Red Hill, Canberra, by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times in the dining room. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse, which compromised his mental state during the attack. Mullen's assessment, supported by evidence like Costa's fluctuating mood during emergency calls and a trail of faeces from the crime scene, suggests Costa was in a confused state and may not have understood his actions or their consequences. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold questioned the authenticity of Costa's memory issues, but Mullen maintained his belief in Costa's dementia. The jury could return a not guilty verdict if Costa's unstable mental state at the time of the attack is proven.

In Everton's 1-0 victory over Burnley at Goodison Park, Ross Barkley took a 10th-minute penalty instead of the usual taker, Leighton Baines, who has a strong record of 15 successful penalties out of 16 in the Premier League. Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Everton manager Roberto Martinez supported Barkley's decision to take the penalty, emphasizing the importance of players taking responsibility in key moments and mentioning that multiple players, including Romelu Lukaku, are capable of taking penalties depending on their confidence at the time. Despite the miss, Everton won the match thanks to a goal by Kevin Mirallas in the 29th minute.

Two passengers on the Holland America Line's ms Ryndam were found dead in their stateroom in what appears to be a murder-suicide. The incident occurred at 11:30 a.m. on Thursday while the ship was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico, during a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise that had departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29. The cabin was secured, and the FBI and local authorities were notified and are investigating the incident, with the cruise line fully cooperating. The bodies were discovered by the ship's cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to advance in the 2018 World Cup qualifying rounds. As coach, he guided the team to a 4-3 aggregate victory over Montserrat, securing their place in the second round of CONCACAF qualifiers. Curacao will next face Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, who has personal ties to Curacao through his mother, previously reached the World Cup semi-finals as a player in 1998 and as an assistant coach in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, a seasoned footballer with a history of winning major European competitions, views keeping Leicester City in the Premier League as equivalent to winning a trophy. Leicester, struggling at the bottom of the league table, faces a critical situation with only eight games left in the season. Despite the challenges, Cambiasso remains optimistic about avoiding relegation, emphasizing the team's potential to win crucial matches. He joined Leicester on a one-year deal and has become a key player, expressing satisfaction with his life in the East Midlands and openness to extending his stay.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two young children, faces a potential ban from seeing her kids imposed by her mother, Debbie, who has been their primary caregiver since they were four months old. Debbie's decision stems from Gemma's ongoing issues with drinking, partying, and using the legal high MKat, as well as suspicions of theft, including an iPad allegedly stolen from one of the children. Despite Gemma's denial of stealing the iPad, she admits to past thefts from her mother. Debbie, frustrated and at her limit, is prepared to enforce this ban due to Gemma's lack of responsibility and care towards her children, who call Debbie "mum." This situation was highlighted on The Jeremy Kyle Show, where a lie detector test confirmed Gemma's theft.

During a match at Stamford Bridge, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored the opening goal against Manchester United, following a controversial play. Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao, causing him to fall and lose the ball. Cesc Fabregas then picked up the loose ball, leading to a sequence that ended with Hazard scoring. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness unanimously agreed during halftime that Terry's challenge on Falcao was a foul and the play should have been stopped.

Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, but all passengers, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blew out, and it destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except Scott's Bible. The incident was captured on video by Michael Barnett. The other two members of Lady Antebellum, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus at the time. The band is scheduled to perform at the Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is developing space lasers to convert sunlight into energy for heating homes, with successful initial trials in Scotland and plans to expand testing to Portugal. These lasers, which use satellites equipped with mirrors and semiconductors to capture and convert sunlight into laser beams sent back to Earth, could make solar power viable in less sunny regions like Scotland and provide instant power to disaster-stricken areas. Unlike the powerful lasers seen in science fiction, these are designed to be safe and not weaponizable, though Quarterman acknowledges potential control concerns. In contrast, researchers in Tokyo are working on a different laser system for the International Space Station to clear space debris, targeting small objects up to 62 miles away to burn them in Earth's atmosphere, also not powerful enough for weapon use.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a 'fanatical obsession' with young girls, escaped from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, at 6:15 pm on Tuesday. Munden, who was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus, is described as about 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, with dark hair. He may have shaved his beard before leaving the hospital. Munden was previously convicted of possessing indecent images of children and was sentenced to a hospital order following his latest offence. He has learning difficulties and autism, which affect his ability to control his sexual interest in small children. Authorities are urgently seeking information on his whereabouts.

V. Stiviano was ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts to Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, following a lawsuit claiming Stiviano targeted wealthy older men. These gifts, funded by Donald Sterling's marital assets, included luxury cars and other items. The lawsuit stemmed from Donald Sterling's racist remarks that led to his ban from the NBA and the loss of his ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers. Stiviano argued that the gifts were legitimate, but the court ruled in favor of Shelly Sterling, setting a precedent for recovering damages from recipients of such gifts.

Thierry Henry, a former Arsenal player and current Sky Sports pundit, has criticized Arsenal's transfer strategy and emphasized the need for the club to sign four key players in the upcoming summer transfer window to compete for the Premier League title. He specified the need for a goalkeeper, a centre back, a defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker. Henry made these comments following Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, where he also questioned whether Arsenal could win the league with Olivier Giroud as their first-choice striker, despite Giroud's 14 league goals this season. Henry referenced Chelsea's successful signings of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as examples of the caliber of players Arsenal should target. At the time of his comments, Arsenal were third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

A young woman, a victim of Maurice Van Ryn, the Bega Cheese boss, spoke in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of his abuse on her life. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who kept the abuse secret until Van Ryn was caught, expressed fears about her future relationships and the lasting effects of the abuse, which she did not understand as wrong during her childhood. She has struggled with depression, self-harm, and attempted suicide since the age of 14. Van Ryn remained calm and did not look at her during the court session. The victim worries about Van Ryn's eventual release and its impact on her life.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering well from a serious knee injury that sidelined him since March 2014. He recently played full matches for Arsenal's Under-21 team, marking his progress towards returning to the first team. Gnabry expressed optimism about his recovery, noting he feels 'better and better' and is looking forward to future games.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling 70ft off a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while trying to avoid paying a taxi fare. After a night out drinking in Cardiff with friends Padraig Crowley and Rory Robinson, they took a taxi but lacked the funds to pay. The group attempted to use an ATM but then fled; Phillips ran into the dark, leapt over a fence, and fell to his death at the base of the cliff on the disused Northern Promenade. His body was found the next morning by a dog walker. The coroner ruled his death accidental, noting Phillips was likely disoriented and unaware of the danger due to the darkness.

Last summer, thousands of holidaymakers affected by passport delays did not receive compensation, despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit and managers receiving up to £3,500 in bonuses. The crisis began when HM Passport Office struggled with 3.6 million applications, leading to over half a million passports stuck in the system by mid-June. Although ministers offered a free fast-track service for urgent cases, many had already paid extra for this service and still missed trips. Only 2,191 compensation claims were approved out of thousands, with a total payout of £203,066, averaging £92.68 per claim. The Home Affairs Committee, led by Keith Vaz, criticized the lack of compensation, especially given the agency's profits, but ministers rejected a blanket refund policy to avoid setting a precedent.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, is up for sale with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. The semi-detached property, untouched for over 80 years, features original elements such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a wood-panelled hallway, and vintage cupboards. The house includes a three-bedroom layout with an original bathroom in mint green and black, a kitchen with dated features like a brick open-face fire, and retro jars of food from brands like Cadbury’s and Tate and Lyle. Despite some upgrades like double glazing, the potential renovation costs might deter developers. The home, considered a collector's paradise, will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and was released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, lived there during her early years before relocating to Texas and then San Francisco. Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone and Colchester, met Graham Coxon at Stanway School and formed Blur. Albarn's solo album "Everyday Robots," released on April 28, 2014, was co-produced by Richard Russell and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and others, including samples from Lord Buckley.

The TV series "Shooter" stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile, who returns to action upon discovering a plot to assassinate the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, orchestrated by members of his group. He was also convicted for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Following his charges, commercial recordings of songs written and performed by Manson were released.

Sean Justin Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He started his career on television with a role in "Little House on the Prairie" in 1974, directed by his father Leo Penn. His film career began with "Taps" in 1981, followed by notable roles in the 1980s including "Fast Times at Ridgemont High." Penn gained critical acclaim for his performances in crime dramas such as "At Close Range," "State of Grace," and "Carlito's Way." He achieved prominence with "Dead Man Walking" in 1995, earning his first Academy Award nomination and a Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received further Oscar nominations for "Sweet and Lowdown" and "I Am Sam," and won Best Actor Oscars for "Mystic River" in 2003 and "Milk" in 2008.

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, born on August 27, 1908, and passed away on February 25, 2001, was an Australian cricketer renowned as the greatest batsman ever. After retiring, he remained influential in cricket as an administrator, selector, and writer for thirty years.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards, born on September 1, 1933, and died on September 13, 2006, was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She was a Democrat who gained national recognition after delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention while serving as the state treasurer of Texas. Richards was defeated in her re-election bid in 1994 by George W. Bush. She was the second female governor of Texas and known for her outspoken feminism and witty one-liners. Aristotle, born in 384 BC in Stagira, Greece, was a philosopher and scientist. He joined Plato's Academy at age 17 or 18 and stayed until he was 37. After Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and later tutored Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon starting in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American who was previously an arms dealer. He has since become a musician, inventor, and entrepreneur, notably inventing the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine. He currently serves as the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning championships in high school and college before being drafted first overall in the 1979 NBA draft. He secured five championships with the Lakers, including one in his rookie year where he also earned an NBA Finals MVP. After retiring and returning briefly in 1996 at age 36, he retired permanently after playing 32 more games. Johnson was recognized as a significant black businessman by Ebony magazine in 2009 and has various business interests, including a past stake in the Lakers.

Tenacious D, formed in 1994 in Los Angeles, is a comedy rock duo consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: "Tenacious D" (2001), "The Pick of Destiny" (2006), and "Rize of the Fenix" (2012). The duo gained fame starting in 1997 with their TV series and by opening for major rock bands.

James VI and I, born on June 19, 1566, and died on March 27, 1625, was King of Scotland as James VI from July 24, 1567, and King of England and Ireland as James I from March 24, 1603, until his death. He ruled Scotland and England in a personal union, with each having separate parliaments, judiciary, and laws. James advocated for a unified parliament for both countries, succeeding more in Scotland than in England, where he encountered significant challenges including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 and ongoing conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the eighteenth series of the British reality TV show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. He also provided continuity announcements for Channel 4 until July 2011, when he left to narrate Big Brother on Channel 5. Bentley's Geordie accent has made him one of Britain's most recognized voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordered by several German states and the countries of Poland and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest German state by area, covering 18,413 km2, and the sixth most populous with 4 million residents. Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and is known for its quality wine production, being one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe and one of only two wine regions in former East Germany.
East End Park was a major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood. Additionally, "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career with the release of the song "I Want You Back," which featured Missy Elliott and was released on Virgin Records.

"Mohra," a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, features lead actors Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah, with supporting roles by Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar. Released on July 1, 1994, it became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Her personal life, including her relationship with Ben Affleck, influenced her 2002 album "This Is Me... Then," and impacted the reception of the film "Gigli" in 2003. Lopez later married Marc Anthony and starred in the successful film "Shall We Dance?" She gave birth to twins in 2008. After a less successful period, she regained prominence in 2011 as a judge on "American Idol" and with her hit single "On the Floor," one of the best-selling singles of all time.

A working animal is typically a domesticated animal trained by humans to perform various tasks. These tasks can range from being guide or assistance dogs, to providing tractive force like draft horses or logging elephants, to milking or herding. Occasionally, wild animals are trained for work, mainly for novelty or entertainment, but they generally lack the trustworthiness and mild temperament of domesticated working animals.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, initially by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later by World Championship Wrestling (WCW). Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) under the NWA banner produced several Starrcade events, including the third in 1985, the fifth in 1987, and the fifteenth in 1997. Seohyun, born Seo Ju-hyun on June 28, 1991, is a South Korean singer and actress who debuted with the girl group Girls' Generation in 2007, later joining its subgroup TTS. The Apple II, introduced in 1977, is an 8-bit home computer and one of the first successful mass-produced microcomputers. Artpop, an album by Lady Gaga, received mixed reviews from critics but was a commercial success. It debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 in the U.S., selling 258,000 copies in its first week, marking Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the U.S. with total sales reaching 757,000 copies. Globally, Artpop was the ninth best-selling album of 2013, selling 2.3 million copies worldwide.
In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, titled "Stadium Arcadium." This album was the last to feature Frusciante, who left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She remains a controversial figure, celebrated as a highly influential politician in British history, though debates about Thatcherism continue.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born on February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Beyond his music career, he has also made a name for himself as a writer, contributing weekly columns to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com on diverse subjects.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has not only acted but also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially known as València, is the capital of the Valencian Community, an autonomous region in Spain. It is the third largest city in Spain with approximately 800,000 residents in its administrative center, and its metropolitan area has a population between 1.7 and 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
"Make It or Break It" concluded with its third season being the final one, as announced on April 26, 2012. The series finale was broadcast on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a sub-field of computational linguistics that involves developing technologies to convert spoken language into text, drawing on linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.
