Applications of SR include voice user interfaces for tasks like voice dialing, call routing, controlling домotic appliances, searching for specific spoken content, data entry, document preparation, and speech-to-text processing in various settings including aircraft. The field has seen significant advancements, particularly through the widespread adoption of deep learning methods by major industry players such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC, which have integrated these technologies into their speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf, born on January 26, 1952, and passed away on January 4, 2012, was an American businessman and former comic book store owner. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International, originally named the Golden State Comic Book Convention, in 1970 alongside Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. Alf also served as the chairman of the convention starting in 1970.
"Fist of Legend" is a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury," originally starring Bruce Lee as the lead character.

In the golf tournament, France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par, after Dubuisson scored a 67. Rory McIlroy, aiming for his first title since May, is at 15 under par alongside Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat, following his third consecutive 67. McIlroy's round featured an eagle on the 12th hole and a recovery from earlier mistakes with a birdie and another eagle. Despite a recent ankle injury, McIlroy is competing for a third Race to Dubai title in four years, currently leading Danny Willett. Other notable scores include England's Chris Wood at 13 under and Richard Bland at 12 under.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized the need for meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, insisting that the government must offer concrete solutions and that a representative from the royal family should participate. The dialogue process, recently agreed upon between the government and six opposition societies, faces opposition from hardliners, including the long-serving Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa. Despite skepticism among young protesters, Sheikh Salman sees dialogue as essential, advocating for cooperation with reformists like Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, who supports a constitutional monarchy. A previous agreement for reform was disrupted by the intervention of Gulf Co-operation Council troops in 2011. Sheikh Salman expressed hope in the new US Secretary of State John Kerry to push for human rights and democracy in Bahrain more effectively than his predecessor. He criticized the UK's approach as insufficient, urging public pressure to end violence and human rights abuses. Al-Wefaq plans to continue peaceful demonstrations despite bans and demands the release of imprisoned opposition leaders and activists, crucial for successful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a key figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral is to be private, followed by a public memorial service. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 CDs, including a complete cycle of Mozart's symphonies on period instruments. Notable among his recordings is the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, recognized as one of the top 20 recordings by BBC Music Magazine. He studied at Cambridge University and held various positions, including keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, and was involved with several other music institutions. Colleagues and peers praised his generosity, academic prowess, and significant contributions to historically informed music performance.

In the year ending March, Scotland recorded 57 homicide cases, the lowest since 1976 and a decrease from the previous year's 62 cases. By March 31, 2016, only one case from 2015-16 remained unresolved. Sharp instruments, primarily knives, were used in 51% of these homicides. About 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts in education and enforcement to combat violent crime, while also highlighting initiatives to prevent youth involvement in crime. Scottish Labour's Claire Baker cautioned against over-optimism due to potential revisions in statistics, noting a rise in other violent crimes and sexual offenses.

Bournemouth, known as the Cherries, lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking Sunderland's first Premier League win of the season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's only goal, ending their three-game scoring drought. Despite creating numerous scoring opportunities, Bournemouth failed to equalize even after Steven Pienaar's red card left Sunderland with 10 players. Goals from Victor Anichebe and a penalty by Jermain Defoe secured the win for Sunderland. Bournemouth's manager, Eddie Howe, expressed frustration over the team's inability to convert chances into goals, referencing their previous high-scoring game against Hull.

Mr Abbott stated that the only way to prevent migrant deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," a policy Australia implements by detaining migrants who arrive by boat and processing them in offshore camps for resettlement elsewhere. The New York Times criticized this approach as "brutal," "inhumane," and contrary to Australia's tradition of welcoming refugees. Amidst European considerations of similar policies, the death of Syrian toddler Alan Kurdi highlighted the human cost of such journeys. Additionally, Mr Abbott controversially compared the Islamic State to the Nazis, suggesting IS was worse due to their open boasting of evil acts, a statement that drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups for inappropriately equating terrorism with the systematic genocide of the Holocaust.

Washington accused Russia and the Syrian government of escalating attacks on civilians, leading the US to suspend bilateral talks with Russia aimed at sustaining a ceasefire. This decision followed intensified bombings in Aleppo, including strikes on a main trauma hospital in the rebel-held east. The US criticized Russia for not adhering to ceasefire agreements and for targeting critical infrastructure and blocking humanitarian aid, notably citing an attack on a humanitarian convoy on September 19. Russia denied involvement in the convoy attack and regretted the US's decision to halt talks, accusing the US of failing to meet agreement terms and shifting blame. The breakdown in talks also led to the cancellation of a planned meeting in Geneva to coordinate strikes against jihadist groups, and the US withdrew personnel intended for a joint implementation center. Despite the suspension, both countries agreed to continue discussions on counter-terrorism to prevent unintended conflicts.

The Policy Exchange report, supported by Downing Street, suggests that selling high-value vacant social homes could generate £4.5 billion annually, enabling the construction of 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes. This could be the largest social house building program since the 1970s and potentially reduce the social housing waiting list by about 500,000 from the current 1.8 million. The report identifies 816,000 expensive social homes (21.8% of the total stock) that could be sold, with London holding over £70 billion worth. Critics, including Labour and the National Housing Federation, argue that this could displace low-income families from affluent areas, leading to segregated communities. Labour proposes using a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes instead. The government, while supportive of the sell-off, has introduced reforms and invested £19.5 billion in an affordable housing program aiming to deliver up to 170,000 homes.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, died at home after being treated for asthma and subsequently developing a rash. An inquest into his death is pending further tests to determine if measles, confirmed by lab tests, was the cause, amid a local epidemic with 942 cases. Since the outbreak started in November, 83 individuals required hospital treatment. His family, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, were unaware of how he contracted measles.

Vincent Hudson, a 54-year-old from Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence against a boy under 16, which allegedly occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear in North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Neil Aspin's Gateshead, chasing promotion, remained unbeaten in nine National League games, while Adam Lockwood's Guiseley were unbeaten in five. Guiseley scored first against the run of play in the 15th minute through Jake Lawlor, assisted by James Hurst from a throw-in. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute when Wes York capitalized on a slip by Guiseley's substitute Derek Asamoah, scoring from the edge of the box. The match ended in a 1-1 draw. Key moments included defensive actions by Gateshead's Liam Hogan and Guiseley's goalkeeper Jonny Maxted, and substitutions and yellow cards for both teams.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands at their football club to increase capacity, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which faces delays due to a town green application. The redevelopment was approved by Bristol City Council in November. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown announced at a shareholder meeting that work would begin, pending the signing of a section 106 agreement and a six-week judicial review period. If no judicial review is filed by March, redevelopment will start in May.

Cuadrilla suspended its fracking operations in Lancashire after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, to analyze data and consult with experts. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is monitoring the fracking and noted similarities between the recent tremor and a previous 2.3 magnitude earthquake in April near Poulton-le-Fylde. Fracking, which involves fracturing shale rocks to release gas, has been linked to these seismic events. The process remains controversial, with environmental concerns in the US, though the UK's energy select committee supports it with strict regulations. The BGS confirmed that injecting pressurized water into rocks can cause earthquakes, and their instruments detected the latest quake at a depth of about 2km near the drilling site.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud but cleared of two others. He was charged after playing his bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner in April 2015, which led to accusations of misleading the public into thinking he was collecting money for the campaign. Carpenter claimed he was not collecting funds for the charity, despite having previously performed for them, and that the banner was a tribute to the victims. The chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign confirmed he had allowed Carpenter to use the banner but not for fundraising. Carpenter, known for busking in a kilt around Anfield on match days, awaits sentencing in January.

In the match between Ipswich Town and Queens Park Rangers, Ipswich secured a 3-0 victory. Grant Ward scored the first goal with a scuffed shot, followed by Luke Varney's goal into an empty net after a mistake by QPR's goalkeeper Alex Smithies. Tom Lawrence completed the scoring with a composed finish from a Cole Skuse shot. Despite chances to score more, Ipswich's Christophe Berra and Skuse missed opportunities. QPR, managed by Ian Holloway in his second game, struggled offensively, with their best chance being a header by substitute Sandro that hit the post. The win moved Ipswich up to 14th place, overtaking QPR who dropped to 15th. Post-match, Ipswich's manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance and highlighted the impact of players like Varney, while Holloway lamented his team's defensive errors and lack of mental toughness.

Luke Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, performed well in the T20 Blast, scoring 373 runs with an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed optimism about his club's future and praised the elite performance environment fostered by the coaches, which motivates the players.

The Reds, ranked fifth in National Two South, secured a 29-12 victory over third-placed Chinnor, marking their second consecutive win. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were pivotal, leading from the front with the front row and five making over 70 tackles. Upcoming matches include seven teams below them in the standings and the league leaders, Old Elthamians. Coach Churcher noted room for improvement, describing the Chinnor game as emotionally strong but not a complete performance, emphasizing the need to build on this effort to avoid wasting the previous week's progress.

Nazrul, also known as Nazu, a 28-year-old Bangladeshi man, was arrested at a Kolkata railway station for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun during an attack on a convent in Ranaghat town on March 14. This incident, which also involved theft and vandalism at the convent school, sparked widespread protests across India. Nazrul is the sixth person arrested in connection with the crime, with eight suspects identified in total, and two still at large. The other five arrested previously identified Nazrul as the perpetrator of the rape. Police acted on a tip that Nazrul, who had fled to Bangladesh after being identified on CCTV, was returning to Kolkata by train. Milon Sarkar, arrested earlier in May, was described as the leader of the gang involved in the attack, though his specific role remained unclear.

The passage discusses an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, which may not be compatible with older browsers. The video explains how changes in consumer buying habits in the UK have been influenced by the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also covers shifts in ownership and rankings of major UK brands. A non-interactive version of the content is available, along with links to additional related information on topics such as Chinese ownership, food freezing tips, and a survey of the top 20 consumer brands in the UK.

Two women, one from Sandyhills and one from Stranraer, were victims of scams by individuals falsely claiming to be from BT technical support. The Sandyhills incident occurred on September 15, and the Stranraer incident happened a week later. The scammers gained remote access to the victims' computers and stole money. PC Siobhan Pellett warned about the ease of these scams and urged the public never to give out banking details over the phone, as legitimate businesses do not request such information this way.

Duffy, aged 37, has signed a one-year contract with a third-placed Championship team after departing from Swinton Lions. As the new Scotland assistant coach, he will manage Featherstone in their last league match against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy's coaching skills and his successful tenure at Swinton under challenging conditions. Duffy, who previously played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford over 16 years, has been succeeded by Stuart Littler at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew and a coastguard helicopter responded to an incident at Sker Beach on Sunday at 12:50 GMT. A rider with head injuries, found unconscious and cold on wet sand, was treated on-site by the crew, including a medic, before being airlifted to University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff.

At a UN conference in Geneva, over 160 countries agreed to allocate a radio frequency for a global flight tracking system using satellite technology, prompted by the disappearance of MH370 in 2014. This new system will use automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) to enable real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide, addressing the weaknesses exposed by MH370's loss, which left 70% of global airspace uncovered. The decision was made at the World Radiocommunication Conference organized by the ITU, with the International Civil Aviation Organisation setting a deadline of November 2016 for new tracking guidelines, requiring aircraft to report their position at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, was found at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby, aged 53, was arrested and is detained at Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. The FBI, tipped off on October 30 due to issues with Julian's college application, confirmed his identity with help from Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Bobby is also charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. Julian's mother has been informed of his recovery. Authorities suspected Bobby's involvement in the disappearance since 2002, when he was supposed to take Julian to preschool but fled instead.

Following a fire on March 2 at a site on Duncan Street, firefighters were present for several days, leading to reduced train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and later revoked their environmental permit, effective from August 7, unless appealed by that date. The company, operated by Asset and Land Group, was described as "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS), who had visited the site nine times in the last year. Prior to the fire, GMFRS had expressed concerns to the EA about potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment, leading to joint visits and subsequent enforcement action by the EA. The cause of the fire remains undetermined, and the company must remove all waste from the site.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, proposed two bills related to the crisis in Ukraine, particularly in Crimea. The first bill would allow Crimea to join Russia if its leaders request it or a referendum is held, bypassing the need for a treaty with Ukraine, which is required under current Russian law. This change is justified by the party as necessary due to Ukraine's instability. The second bill aims to expedite the process for Ukrainians, especially Russian-speaking ones, to obtain Russian citizenship. It removes requirements such as state tax, previous residence in Russia, sufficient funds, and renunciation of Ukrainian citizenship. The bill also shortens the citizenship waiting period from one year to two months and allows applications at Russian diplomatic missions until August 1. Several Russian MPs, including notable figures, have visited Crimea in relation to these developments.

The passage discusses McLaren's decline from its past successes in Formula 1. Historically, McLaren has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and 8 constructors' titles, with notable success during partnerships with Honda and Mercedes. However, since 2013, the team has struggled, particularly with the Honda power-unit despite improvements in car design. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998 with Mika Hakkinen, and they were controversially disqualified from the 2007 constructors' championship due to a scandal involving Ferrari's technical information. McLaren's history shows cycles of success and decline, with significant achievements under team principal Ron Dennis, who returned in 2013 to reverse the team's fortunes. Despite current struggles, Dennis and the team remain optimistic about future success, believing in the potential of their car and the upcoming improvements from Honda. The passage highlights the challenges and hopes surrounding McLaren, with a focus on their storied past and uncertain future.

Thomas Baker, known as Tommy, a 44-year-old from Everton, was fatally shot at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on January 27. He was attacked after leaving Phoenix Gym and was shot in the head and chest while getting into his car. Three men from Liverpool, aged 29 and 32, have been arrested and are in custody. The police are searching for a silver VW Polo seen leaving the scene quickly and are also seeking information from individuals captured on CCTV near the market, as they may hold crucial details for the investigation.

The passage discusses various ways to engage with Christmas themes online, focusing on spiritual and religious content. It highlights Everyday Church Online, which offers virtual services and a Star Wars-themed Christmas sermon called "The Hope Awakens," aimed at a global audience. Guardians of Ancora, a free-to-play game for children aged 8-11, features Bible-themed quests, including the nativity story, to help players restore light to a fictional world. The passage also mentions successful online nativity videos, such as "The Digital Story of Nativity" by Viral.de, which uses social media platforms to narrate the story, and "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle" by the Churches Advertising Network, which faced challenges in cinema screenings due to its religious content. Additionally, Next Manga has launched digital versions of its Manga Messiah, a nativity story in Japanese comic style, available in multiple languages and distributed to refugees. The passage concludes by noting the use of social media by religious groups to connect with communities and share spiritual messages during the Christmas season.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is focused on a proposal to develop 250 hectares of common land, with 320 hectares offered as replacement by supporters including Blaenau Gwent council. The inquiry has revealed disagreements among experts regarding the environmental impact, particularly on habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales found it challenging to assess the replacement land's equivalence but did not oppose the project. Conversely, an ecology report from the developers claims a potential "net gain" in biodiversity due to planned enhancements of nearby habitats, a claim contested by the Gwent wildlife trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will provide a recommendation post-inquiry, with the final decision resting with Welsh government ministers.

Chechen Muslim clerics, after a meeting on 3 April, condemned a Novaya Gazeta report from 1 April that revealed the detention and killing of over 100 homosexual men in Chechnya, calling it an insult to their faith and dignity. The clerics' resolution hinted at retribution against those responsible for the report. Novaya Gazeta interpreted this as a call for reprisals against journalists and urged Russian authorities to prevent actions against them. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy, detailing torture in a prison near Argun. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesman denied the allegations, with the latter claiming no gay people exist in Chechnya. The spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, supported the call for retribution. Novaya Gazeta's report also mentioned the detention of influential clerics and TV presenters. The newspaper's chief editor, Dmitry Muratov, defended their work and sought dialogue. The report's context includes the murders of Novaya Gazeta reporters and opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, who investigated Chechen crimes. The LGBT Network is assisting victims to flee and may file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia does not prosecute those responsible.

Investing Solutions, a company set up by Samir Patel in 2002, has been receiving housing benefit payments for housing single homeless men over 35, facilitated by the charity Fresh Start Housing, which Patel established in 2010. Both entities operate from the same south London storage unit and focus on seven London boroughs. Fresh Start Housing refers clients to Investing Solutions and private landlords, having housed 788 homeless people since its inception, including 222 in the last year. 

Investing Solutions profits by placing multiple unrelated tenants in a single house and charging housing benefit for each, resulting in higher total payouts than the rent passed to landlords. For instance, they claimed £2,114 monthly for two tenants in one property, while paying the landlord £1,150, yielding an annual profit of £11,568 from that property alone. Over two years, nearly half of their £2.1 million in benefits came from Wandsworth Council.

Criticism has arisen regarding the suitability of the accommodations provided, with tenant Nigel McCann reporting severe issues like lack of heating, rats, and damp. The relationship between Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing has been described as "a new low" by homeless charity Crisis, due to the perceived exploitation of vulnerable people for profit. Samir Patel defends the operations, emphasizing that most rent goes to private landlords and expressing concern over allegations about property conditions.

In a warm-up game before the Eurobasket qualifiers, Great Britain's basketball team, led by Coach Joe Prunty, was defeated by the Netherlands despite leading for most of the first three quarters. Andrew Lawrence and NBA player Ben Gordon scored 14 and 13 points respectively for GB, with Gordon notably hitting three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter. The Netherlands, spearheaded by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, took the lead in the fourth quarter and won the game. GB is set to start their Eurobasket qualifying campaign in Hungary. Coach Prunty emphasized the importance of intensity on both offense and defense for the upcoming qualifiers and praised Gordon's performance, noting his effort to find rhythm with the team.

The former five-weight world champion, McGregor, submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use 8oz gloves for his boxing debut against Mayweather, set at 154 lbs where 10oz gloves are standard. The NAC, which sanctioned the bout, will debate this request on 16 August. Mayweather, coming out of retirement, had previously expressed interest in using lighter gloves but had not submitted the waiver at the time. The use of lighter gloves could lead to more punishing punches but offers less hand protection. NAC's executive director, Bob Bennett, emphasized the commission's focus on fighter safety and noted the unprecedented nature of this request at this weight class. McGregor, transitioning from UFC where he used 4oz gloves, has been approved to fight Mayweather despite criticisms from boxing figures. Bennett's approval was influenced by McGregor's performance against Nate Diaz and other factors like McGregor's age, reach, and resilience. McGregor's preparation included hiring boxing referee Joe Cortez, amidst a controversial sparring session with Paulie Malignaggi, who subsequently left the camp.

The passage discusses the closure of the London office of the Dundee-based Sunday Post, marking the end of an era for Fleet Street, historically the hub of British journalism. Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, the last journalists based there, shared their experiences and memories of the street. Fleet Street was once central to the nation's newspapers, with its peak described as a bustling area filled with journalists, pubs, and printing presses. The street's decline began with the relocation of major newspapers in the 1980s, led by Rupert Murdoch, to more modern facilities, resulting in the transformation of the area into commercial spaces. The passage reflects on the historical significance of Fleet Street, its cultural impact, and the personal stories of those who worked there, including the challenges and the vibrant social life. After the closure, Smith plans to work as a freelance journalist, while Sherriff intends to write his memoirs.

J.K. Rowling, the Harry Potter author, faced significant online abuse on Twitter, particularly after donating £1m to the No vote campaign in the Scottish independence referendum and previously to the Labour party. She expressed frustration with abusive comments, describing them as crossing a personal line and likened standing up to such bullies to being a famous woman on Twitter. Rowling blocked some abusive users, believed to be supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP), after being called a traitor for her political views. Despite the negativity, she engaged positively with other SNP supporters, noting political commonalities. Amidst the criticism, she humorously responded to a suggestion that her books be publicly burned by offering to bring marshmallows. The SNP achieved a strong performance in the recent election, securing 56 out of 59 seats in Scotland, making it the third largest party in the UK.

The University of Edinburgh's study, tracking 4,300 young people since 1998, found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crimes as their better-off peers. Poverty increases the likelihood of violence among both genders, with boys being three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, and girls from poorer backgrounds twice as likely as those from affluent homes to be involved in violent crime. The study also revealed that a history of police trouble strongly predicts whether a young person will be out of education, employment, or training by age 18. Poorer youth are five times more likely to be under statutory supervision. The research highlighted that poverty exacerbates the risk of offending, even when other risk factors are considered, and that contact with the juvenile justice system can perpetuate the conditions conducive to violence. Despite a general decline in crime rates in Scotland, the most deprived communities continue to experience high crime rates, often correlating with high levels of chronic health problems and unemployment. The Scottish government claims progress in making Scotland safer and addressing poverty and inequality, despite these findings.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in the Marian estate, Kilkee, early Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh, 25, from Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and remanded in custody until his next court appearance. Two other men arrested were released without charge, with files sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is alleged that Walsh and two others entered the estate around 01:00, sought out Mr. Haugh, and a fight involving weapons ensued, leading to Mr. Haugh's death from a stab wound. Additional individuals joined the fight, and police recovered knives and golf clubs at the scene, including a blood-stained knife blade. Mr. Haugh was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00. Tensions in Kilkee have risen due to the incident.

Phil Flanagan, a Fermanagh MLA, tweeted in May 2014 accusing Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, of harassment and shooting during his service. The tweet was deleted within an hour, but the issue escalated to the High Court. The court heard that Elliott has a clear record with the MoD. Flanagan was required to apologize on Twitter by the end of Friday, admitting his tweet was "untrue and wholly without foundation." The court has yet to decide on compensation, and Flanagan's insurance will not cover any potential costs, leading him to challenge this in a separate court action. Elliott expressed satisfaction with the outcome, though disappointed with the duration of the process.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874 and recently acquired by Benny Hartop, has increased its sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 per week due to strong demand. This surge is driven by successful sales of their new branded range launched in January, as well as growth in their established private label business. The company, which employs over 230 staff, sells its products in several European countries including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain, as well as in the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Managing Director Benny Hartop attributes the company's positive outlook to the dedication of its staff and expects continued success.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, was seriously injured outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December when struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf. Wright, 55, admitted to hitting Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun. The incident occurred as Blackburn was escorting a woman and her child across the road when the traffic lights were red. Wright failed to stop at the red light, resulting in the collision. Blackburn, a mother of three and a lollipop lady for 20 years, is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse in court, stating he has been deeply affected by the incident. The trial at Luton Crown Court continues.

The passage describes a NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose," focusing on the hunt for the German U-boat U33, which simulates an enemy submarine. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland, and is a response to increased Russian submarine activity in the region. The U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf, aims to evade detection and target the USS Vicksburg and an oil tanker. The exercise highlights the challenges of anti-submarine warfare, likened to finding a needle in a haystack, and involves the use of sonar, sensors, and for the first time, underwater drones. The passage also points out a significant gap in Britain's defenses due to the lack of maritime patrol aircraft, which were previously provided by the Nimrod. This deficiency is seen as a vulnerability, especially with reports of Russian submarines near UK waters. The exercise underscores the need for NATO readiness in anti-submarine warfare and the necessity for Britain to address its defense capabilities in upcoming reviews.

The passage discusses the escalating crisis in South Sudan, where violence has led to potential genocide and ethnic cleansing. Since July, over 340,000 people have fled to Uganda, the highest number of refugees from any country in 2016, surpassing even those from Syria. The violence, initially a conflict between Dinka President Salva Kiir and Nuer former Vice-President Riek Machar, has spread to the Equatoria region, targeting Equatorians. Refugees report severe atrocities including killings, rape, and ethnic targeting. Uganda has managed the influx well, providing refugees with land and resources to start farming within 36 hours of arrival. However, the situation is straining Uganda's resources, with Bidi Bidi becoming one of the world's largest refugee settlements. The UN calls for international attention to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence, highlighting the dire conditions and the impact on civilians, especially children.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old former footballer turned professional boxer since 2013, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight title at York Hall on November 12. With a record of eight wins and one draw in nine fights, he is the son of ex-champion Clinton McKenzie and trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The coalition government has allocated £330m for new NHS facilities in England, including £33m for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and in poor condition. The project is co-funded by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new facility is expected to enhance patient recovery and well-being. In Somerset, three out of 13 community hospitals have been replaced in the last five years, and construction has started on the Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton. The new Bridgwater hospital is planned for Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with a completion target of autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, near Sheffield's city centre, around 13:35 GMT. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest near a black Mercedes he was driving. Despite being rushed to Northern General Hospital, he succumbed to his injuries. The shooting occurred during a family celebration, with relatives attempting to aid him after the shot was heard. The area was secured by armed police. This incident is part of a series of recent shootings in Sheffield, though previous incidents were located in the northern parts of the city, including Shiregreen, Southey Green, and High Green, with varying circumstances and outcomes.

The passage discusses the activities of three prominent hacker groups involved in the Ukraine conflict: Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are pro-Ukrainian and have hacked Russian servers, used DDoS attacks against rebel websites, targeted rebel funding through electronic payment systems, and monitored public CCTV in rebel-held areas. They also hijacked network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans and has hacked Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and vote-counting systems, as well as leaked sensitive documents. Anonymous International, known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, focuses on Russian domestic affairs but also covers Ukraine, publishing leaked documents from the Kremlin. All groups claim to be independent activists, though their actions significantly impact the ongoing conflict.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to the Scottish Parliament ahead of the election on May 5. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, used his valedictory speech to reiterate his belief in Scotland's diversity and the need for the parliament to take on more governance responsibilities. He welcomed new powers under the Scotland Bill but felt it did not meet the promises made during the referendum campaign. Salmond also humorously acknowledged competition from the Cheltenham racecourse and wished varying degrees of luck to election candidates. He emphasized the honor and importance of serving in the parliament. McNeil, stepping down after serving since 1999, warned that the Scottish Parliament needed to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also retiring, humorously mentioned missing her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review on the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She aims to gather experiences from pensioners, their families, and friends to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will assess various aspects of life in care homes, including physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care environment. Rochira has observed both positive impacts of high-quality care and issues with poor care across Wales. Her team will also engage with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. However, the Care Forum Wales expressed disappointment over the lack of a care home expert on the review's advisory panel, suggesting a missed opportunity for more inclusive partnership in the review process.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase to £3.5m for the year ending June 2016, despite a £1m drop in turnover to just over £100m. The company, which specializes in manufacturing and supplying feeds for various livestock sectors, saw growth in international sales, particularly in Europe and new markets. Harbro operates 19 Country Store branded shops across Scotland, serving farming and rural communities with diverse products. The company acknowledges challenging times and uncertainties related to Brexit but remains confident in its robust position within the agriculture industry.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on a Saturday afternoon. Another man in his 80s was hospitalized. The police are treating the death as a murder and are seeking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the crime. McLoughlin is described as a white male, approximately 6ft tall, with greying, collar-length hair and an average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. The public is advised not to approach him. The police are increasing patrols in the area and are asking for information from the public.

David Lipton, the IMF's second in command, highlighted global economic risks in a speech, noting a weakening global economy and a delicate economic juncture. This follows disappointing trade data from China, with exports dropping by 25% year-over-year. The IMF is expected to lower its global growth forecast from 3.4% in its upcoming April report, reflecting ongoing challenges for businesses reliant on China's economic growth.

The council meeting addressed issues with a new chain ferry at Cowes, which has experienced multiple problems since its late launch on May 14, including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. In response, the council decided to make the crossing free until July 2 and ordered an audit of the project. Council leader Dave Stewart acknowledged the frustrating start. Local businesses, like Valu-4-U in East Cowes, have suffered significant trade losses, prompting shopkeeper Angie Booth to question compensation, which transport councillor Ian Ward said was under discussion. The ferry, described as a prototype, has had electrical issues fixed and ramp extensions authorized to prevent vehicle damage, while groundings were attributed to resolved seamanship issues.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man died at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested for allegedly causing death by driving without due care. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, an international temp agency in London, advertised for a personal assistant with specific physical attributes, prompting criticism from the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners for being discriminatory and outdated. The EHRC demanded clarification on the agency's hiring practices. The agency's founder defended the approach, citing client preferences and the importance of first impressions. Another job advert from the agency sought a "sexy female driver," which an employment lawyer deemed unlawful. The agency's practices were criticized for potentially violating the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on various personal characteristics. Matching Models serves high-profile clients and has placed thousands of people worldwide, often fulfilling specific aesthetic requests from clients.

The shooting took place at a hostel connected to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where Mahesh, an office assistant, allegedly shot 18-year-old Gautami and injured another student, Sirisha. Mahesh was arrested following a manhunt and remanded until 12 April. Such incidents are rare in Indian schools and colleges. India has strict gun control laws, yet firearms are often used in settling feuds. A similar incident occurred in 2007 near Delhi, where a schoolboy was killed by classmates.

The advocacy group Glaad's analysis of TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017 identified 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with an increase in transgender characters from seven to 16. However, the report highlighted a concerning trend of over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters being killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith from "Orange is the New Black" and "Wentworth," respectively. The study also noted a record high in black character representation on broadcast TV, largely due to shows like "Empire," "Luke Cage," and "How to Get Away with Murder." Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledged progress but emphasized that numbers alone do not tell the full story.

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, decided not to seek re-election amid controversy over a £10.25m loan from the borough council to Northampton Town FC, which he supported as council leader. The loan, intended for rebuilding Sixfields stadium, is now missing and under police investigation for financial irregularities. The football stand project remains incomplete. Facing potential deselection by his local party, Mackintosh announced his decision before a meeting where opposition to his candidacy was anticipated. He expressed that it was time for new representation for his constituents.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former policeman, fatally shot 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in Balch Springs, Dallas, by firing into a car driving away from a party. The incident occurred after police responded to reports of underage drinking and mistakenly thought they heard gunshots. Initially, police claimed the car moved aggressively towards Oliver, but video evidence showed it was driving away. Oliver was sacked for policy violations shortly after and faces murder charges with a potential sentence of 5 to 99 years, along with four counts of aggravated assault related to other teenagers in the car. No trial date has been set, and Oliver is out on bail. This case could mark the first conviction of a police officer for murder in Dallas County since 1973.

The president-elect announced that Melania Trump and their son Barron will move to Washington after Barron finishes school, though no specific date was given. This decision sparked criticism on social media, with some viewing it as a departure from tradition, as only two other First Ladies, Martha Washington and Anna Harrison, did not live in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. Supporters of Melania's decision argue it reflects responsible parenting, prioritizing Barron's education. Historically, other first families have managed similar transitions; for instance, Frances Folsom Cleveland lived in the White House only during social season, and other presidential children like those of John Tyler and Dolley Madison's son from a previous marriage did not immediately move into the White House or were sent away to school. Recent first families, including the Clintons and Obamas, managed to balance their public roles with family life, with their children living in the White House from the start of their presidencies. Melania Trump has indicated that Barron will be her top priority, suggesting she may not fully engage in the traditional ceremonial and public roles of the First Lady, which have evolved to include supporting various causes, as seen with Michelle Obama's initiatives. There is speculation about whether Ivanka Trump might take on some responsibilities typically associated with the First Lady.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on October 27. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner, Kate Frame, is investigating the initial police response to the man's call, as instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service. Police Scotland is fully cooperating with the investigation, and a report will be submitted to the COPFS upon completion.

A yellow wind warning was issued, with gusts up to 75mph expected, particularly west of the mountains. The unusual easterly wind direction may increase the impact. Travel disruptions are likely on roads and at sea in the counties of Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which is expected to remain closed for most of Monday for cleanup.

In a hockey match, the Giants scored first through Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen tied the game for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay goal for a 2-1 lead, followed by Andy Bohmback's equalizer. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then scored to make it 4-2, with David Ling of Nottingham scoring a late goal. The teams are set to play again on Saturday night. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25 points.

In the Chinese Grand Prix, Lewis Hamilton, starting from the back, faced multiple challenges including a broken front wing on the first lap and five pit stops, finishing the race with a 36-point deficit to close in the remaining 18 races. Sebastian Vettel of Ferrari finished second after a first-lap collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to fifth place. The race saw numerous first-lap incidents, including a collision involving Hamilton and Felipe Nasr, leading to early safety car deployment. Daniel Ricciardo briefly led after overtaking pole-sitter Nico Rosberg at the start but suffered a puncture, allowing Rosberg to win comfortably. Raikkonen overtook Hamilton late in the race, aided by Ferrari's strategic choice of soft tires. Post-race, Vettel and Daniil Kvyat had a heated exchange over a risky move by Kvyat. Hamilton's car suffered significant damage, affecting his performance and recovery throughout the race.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former professional footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, aiming to advance discussion on a topic often ignored in German football. His announcement was met with widespread support from former teammates, football figures, and public personalities. Notable reactions included praise from Arsenal's Lukas Podolski, retired defender Arne Friedrich, and former German Football Association president Theo Zwanziger, who highlighted the courage of Hitzlsperger's action. Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball and Bayern Munich also commended his bravery. Hitzlsperger's decision is seen as a significant step in combating homophobia in football, both in Germany and England. The announcement sparked discussions on the challenges faced by gay footballers, with references to past incidents and the hope that it would encourage more openness about sexuality in the sport. German political figures, including Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman and openly gay politician Volker Beck, expressed support and optimism that Hitzlsperger's action would help break down taboos surrounding homosexuality in football.

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played a key role in Brighton's promotion to the Premier League after 34 years, appearing in 32 Championship games this season. His contract is set to expire, but he is keen on signing a new deal to continue playing in the top flight. Brighton secured promotion with a win over Wigan and are close to clinching the league title, leading Newcastle by four points with two matches left. Sidwell, who was on loan at Brighton from Stoke in 2015-16 before signing a one-year deal in June 2016, has a history of playing in the Premier League with several clubs. He believes he has performed well enough this season to earn a contract extension.

In the match between Blackpool and Colchester United, Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso assisted Jamille Matt in scoring from close range. Colchester equalized shortly after from a corner, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring amidst a goalmouth scramble. Notable moments included Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe making crucial saves, including one from George Elokobi just before halftime. Blackpool missed a chance to win late in the game when Tom Aldred headed wide from a corner. The game ended in a 1-1 draw, with Colchester finishing with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The 29-year-old player, who previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season during their relegation from League One. He is set to possibly debut for Colchester United in their EFL Cup match against Aston Villa. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament spurred increased efforts to establish a permanent police memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. The UK Police Memorial Trust is fundraising £1.5m for the project, which will honor over 1,400 fallen officers and staff. The memorial, expected to be completed by 2019, will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out for families as personal memorials. The government has pledged £1m towards the total £4m cost. The tribute aims to recognize the vital role and sacrifices of police officers in society over the past 250 years.

Manchester United secured a 1-0 victory over Sunderland, maintaining a 15-point lead at the top of the Premier League table with eight games remaining. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on future games rather than past achievements, highlighting their record of 25 wins from the first 30 matches. The next significant match is a derby against Manchester City, where United will have a 15-point advantage. United have accumulated 50 out of a possible 54 points in their last 18 league games and are aiming to surpass Chelsea's record of 95 points set in 2005. Injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea occurred during the Sunderland match, prompting Ferguson to plan changes for the upcoming FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea. Players like Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, Tom Cleverley, Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernandez, and Rio Ferdinand were either rested or not risked in the Sunderland game. Despite a challenging second half, United's first-half performance and determined defending secured the win against a competitive Sunderland side.

Mr Schmidt of Google stated that the company paid the legally required amount of taxes, which amounted to £10m in the UK from 2006 to 2011. He emphasized that tax payment is not optional and that Google would adjust its tax payments according to changes in UK tax laws. Schmidt also expressed confusion over the ongoing debate about taxes and called for international tax reform, suggesting that taxes should be based on where economic activity occurs. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, potentially in secret sessions to bypass confidentiality issues. Google, criticized for minimizing UK tax through routing sales via Ireland, is among the companies targeted. European Union leaders have agreed to implement measures against tax avoidance, including automatic information exchange between tax authorities.

The NHS spent £3.6 billion on agency staff last year, and NHS Improvement aims to reduce this by £1 billion by the end of the current financial year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600 million so far, limiting payments to 55% above normal shift rates for all staff except senior managers. The goal is to lower overall agency staff costs and decrease hospital reliance on them. Despite "promising" progress, the NHS is 10% behind its target, and it's unclear if other pay bill areas have increased. NHS Improvement will soon publish league tables ranking trusts on agency spending and will collect data on the top 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust. There have been instances of hospitals being quoted rates double the cap, such as £130 per hour for a surgeon and £70 per hour for a junior doctor, against caps of £76 and £35 respectively. Jim Mackey, NHS Improvement's chief executive, emphasized the need for further action due to financial constraints.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a bustling commercial hub, now symbolizes Ireland's economic downturn following the Celtic Tiger era. However, signs of recovery are emerging, as noted by local businessman Matt O'Brien, who has seen a business uptick after diversifying into childrenswear and dress hire. Politically, the opposition party Fianna Fáil criticizes the current government's focus on water meters over broadband, with local TD Robert Troy pointing out the lack of foreign investment due to the Industrial Development Authority's inaction. In contrast, the government highlights a potential economic boost from Center Parcs' planned tourism development in Ballymahon, expected to create 1,000 jobs by 2019, though it awaits planning permission. Local Fine Gael TD James Bannon praises the area's tourism potential. Despite these developments, local traders like O'Brien feel more could be done, such as removing parking charges to attract more visitors to the town. Overall, while the midlands show signs of economic recovery, there is a consensus that further efforts are needed.

The competition, concluding on May 29 in the same stadium, involves eight teams playing each other twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs. Key statistics include leading run-scorers David Warner (294 runs), Virat Kohli (267 runs), and AB de Villiers (249 runs); most sixes hit by Warner and De Villiers (12 each); highest individual scores by Quinton de Kock (108) and Warner and Gautam Gambhir (90* each); and leading wicket-takers Mitchell McClenaghan (9 wickets), Bhuvneshwar Kumar (8 wickets), and Mustafizur Rahman (7 wickets). Four England players are participating: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). The passage also lists the fixtures and results schedule from April 25 to May 29, with most games starting at 15:30 BST unless otherwise noted. Updates on scores, fixtures, and results can be followed via BBC Sport.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported an increase of 200 million plastic carrier bags since 2013. These bags, often non-recyclable, contribute to environmental issues by ending up in landfills and rivers. Starting in October, a 5p charge for plastic bags will be implemented in England to promote reuse, following successful reductions in bag usage in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland where similar charges are in place. Campaigners hope this will reduce the environmental impact of discarded bags.

The passage describes severe weather impacts in Wales, including a school roof being damaged in Rhosgadfan, power cuts affecting hundreds of homes, and various transportation disruptions. A yellow wind warning was in effect until midnight on Friday, coinciding with heavy traffic due to the Christmas getaway. The highest wind gusts were recorded on Anglesey, leading to ferry cancellations between Holyhead and Dublin, train delays, and closures of National Trust sites. Restrictions on major bridges were lifted by Friday evening, but the ongoing blustery forecast led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip to December 27th.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about working on a new film with director Ryan Coogler, with whom he previously worked on Creed. He mentioned wanting to put a different spin on his role but did not specify what that role would be. Jordan is also looking forward to working with Lupita Nyong'o, an Oscar winner for her role in 12 Years a Slave, and Chadwick Boseman, who was starring as Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War at the time. Nyong'o had a role in Star Wars: The Force Awakens, and Jordan had previously played the Human Torch in the Fantastic Four reboot. The film Black Panther, featuring Boseman, was set to be released in February 2018.

The theatre at Alexandra Palace, established in 1875, is set to be restored as part of a larger east wing project to transform the palace into a cultural destination. The restoration includes the theatre being used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music, alongside the refurbishment of the BBC studios. The project, costing £26.6m, is funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m), Haringey Council (£6.8m), and Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, which aims to raise the remaining £1m by summer 2017. The theatre, unused for decades but retaining much of its original decor and stage machinery, is planned to reopen in 2018 if fundraising is successful. Additionally, the glazed east court will be converted into a public and exhibition space.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, earned 61 caps for England since his debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner expressed support for the decision made, wishing success to Sam Allardyce, the team, staff, and fans. He also set a record with 46 caps for England's Under-21 team, starting from 2004. His sole international goal was scored during a 5-0 win against Moldova in the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a devastating house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, thanks to her son David, who was awake and noticed the flames. The fire, which started from rubbish burned in a wood stove, rapidly engulfed their home, destroying it completely. Tragically, their pets did not survive. The family escaped in their pajamas, but the community has supported them with donations. Marcy credits David's quick actions for their survival, emphasizing his significant role in saving their lives.

The energy drinks giant considered a £200m offer for West Ham, a club valued at £105m when Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in 2010. They now own over 85% of the club. Since moving to London Stadium, West Ham has been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority share to clear debts, but he and Gold plan for their children to inherit the ownership.

The passage describes a fan-voted awards ceremony in Los Angeles, highlighted by Jillian Bell's comment that it was not the Oscars. The event served as a promotional platform for upcoming summer blockbusters. "The Fault in Our Stars" was the night's big winner, taking home best movie and several awards for its star, Shailene Woodley, including best female performance and best kiss with Ansel Elgort. Other notable winners included Bradley Cooper for best male performance in "American Sniper," Channing Tatum for best comedic performance in "22 Jump Street," and Meryl Streep for best villain in "Into the Woods." Additional winners were Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart received the comedic genius award and brought his children on stage, emphasizing his legacy. Robert Downey Jr. was honored with the Generation Award, joined by his Avengers co-stars. The ceremony also featured previews of upcoming films like "Pitch Perfect 2," "Trainwreck," and "Ultron."

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 player, was loaned from Aberdeen to Dundee United in July and has scored five goals this season. He debuted for Aberdeen in 2012, scoring four goals in 89 appearances. St Mirren's manager Jack Ross praised Smith as a valuable acquisition, noting his maturity and skill, and expressed surprise at securing him from Dundee United. Smith is expected to enhance St Mirren's attacking options. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will face Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to repair 145 potholes daily over the next four months, as the weather has become sufficiently warm. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to fix drainage systems and clear debris from gutters, which were damaged by heavy rain.

In December 2016, at EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland, six Wood Group contractors, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework during a shutdown. The exposure was below the reportable threshold to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), but EnQuest informed HSE and took additional precautionary measures following an investigation. Wood Group prioritized employee safety, conducted medical assessments, and supported the joint investigation with EnQuest. Steve Innes and his colleagues faced cancer fears and ongoing blood tests, feeling that EnQuest failed in its duty of care. The HSE was aware of the incident but did not investigate as it was not reportable under RIDDOR regulations. The Unite union criticized the treatment of the workers and emphasized the need for transparency in safety incidents.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The sculpture, believed to be stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India, was one of 30 items bought from the dealer. The decision to return the sculpture followed a 2012 court case revealing the dealer's manager, Aaron Freedman, had confessed to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The return was prompted by an official request from India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) in May. Although there is no definitive proof of the sculpture's theft, ACM noted Freedman's confession and plans to seek legal compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicentre in Garfagnana. The quake occurred at 15:48 local time and was felt in cities like Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but several aftershocks followed. Phone lines and power supplies were disrupted in the Garfagnana area, and schools were evacuated as a precaution. Italy has a history of deadly earthquakes, including a 2009 quake in L'Aquila that killed nearly 300 people, leading to manslaughter convictions of scientists and an official for providing misleading safety assurances before that event.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, was initially skeptical about growing fruit in South Yorkshire's climate. However, he recently experienced success as the fruit on his plant, though not yet ripe, remains attached, leading him to express great joy.

Rockstar has delayed the release of their latest open-world game from 27 January to 24 March to allow for additional testing and polishing. The company emphasized that this decision was made to enhance the game's quality and is in the best interest of their fans. Alongside this delay, Rockstar announced the introduction of online heists for consoles before the PC version's release. They also released screenshots of the PC version of GTA V, promising enhanced detail with visuals up to 4K resolution and support for triple monitor setups. The minimum PC specifications for running the game have been disclosed. Previously, Grand Theft Auto V set a record as the fastest-selling entertainment product, earning $1 billion in just three days upon its initial release on 17 September 2013.

A 76-year-old artist won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The painting, described as "quite extraordinary" and "difficult to look at" by judge Ansel Krut, depicts a leper squint from medieval churches. The artist, who had been shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, plans to use the prize money for art supplies. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The offices of Turkish newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, both supporting President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's AK Party, were attacked by four masked assailants early on Thursday. The attacks, occurring nearly simultaneously, involved gunfire that shattered windows at both locations, with bullet casings found at the scenes. No casualties were reported, and firefighters extinguished a resulting blaze at the Yeni Safak building. Police have secured the area and are searching for the attackers, with no group yet claiming responsibility. The Yeni Akit office is located 20km from Yeni Safak.

The 24-year-old player, previously on loan at Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, has been signed by Marcus Bignot's team, the Mariners, on a free transfer from the Stags. He will officially join on January 1 and is Bignot's first signing for the team.

Arsene Wenger, whose contract with his club extends to the summer, has been mentioned in connection with the England national team job, currently held by Gareth Southgate on an interim basis. Southgate took over from Sam Allardyce and has led England to a win against Malta and a draw against Slovenia. Wenger praised Southgate's observational skills and experience with the national team, emphasizing the importance of competency over fame in the role. Southgate faces upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain, which could influence his chances of securing the position permanently. Additionally, Wenger discussed Arsenal matters, stating that young defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract amid interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, and that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss upcoming games due to a hamstring injury sustained earlier in the season.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police, in collaboration with the Health and Safety Executive, is conducting an investigation into the incident. The company is fully cooperating with the authorities.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the dispute over seafarers' pay on the freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck under Serco Northlink's contract. The RMT union had reported that some crew members were paid below £4 per hour. The new charter, effective next month, will see services revert to Serco Northlink, ensuring all crew members receive at least the minimum wage. This change follows Seatruck's refusal of Serco Northlink's offers to increase and backdate pay. The Northern Isles ferry service, operated by Serco Northlink since 2012 under a £243m contract, includes three ferries and two cargo boats, subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May following an incident at Rockley Park in Poole on 7 May. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, 57, at a holiday park bar where he got heavily intoxicated. The confrontation between Jamie Mitchell and Mr Dickie escalated outside, leading to Mr Dickie's death. Jamie Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault and, along with his mother, admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying to the police about the incident. They claimed initially that Mr Dickie had pushed Mrs Mitchell, but later Jamie Mitchell said he tried to separate the couple, resulting in a "tragic accident". Both were convicted, with sentencing set for 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a renowned songwriter, passed away at 66 in London after a short battle with cancer. Known for his work with Michael Jackson, including hits like "Off The Wall," "Rock With You," and "Thriller," Temperton's songs contributed significantly to Jackson's success, with "Thriller" becoming the best-selling album in the US. He also wrote for other artists such as Heatwave, for whom he crafted hits like "Boogie Nights." Temperton's influence extended to other musicians like Anita Baker and Aretha Franklin. He won a Grammy in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. Known as "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, Temperton credited his father's influence and his early exposure to Radio Luxembourg for his songwriting prowess. Tributes from figures like Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and Chaka Khan highlighted his impact on music. His private funeral has already taken place, and his family requested privacy during their time of grief.

A team including researchers from Swansea, Exeter, Reading universities, and Brazilian institutions discovered over 450 ancient earthworks, or "geoglyphs," in Acre, Brazil, estimated to be 2,000 years old. These structures, hidden by bamboo rainforest until recent deforestation, are not believed to be villages or defensive structures due to the scarcity of artifacts and their layout. Instead, they might have served as ritual sites similar to the Maya pyramids or Stonehenge, though less visible due to surrounding taller vegetation. Analysis of soil samples by Dr. Neil Loader indicated a diverse range of plant species over 6,000 years, suggesting human influence on the Amazonian ecosystem through selective planting rather than widespread forest burning. This ancient "agroforestry" may have contributed to the biodiversity seen in Acre's forests today.

Nick Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian tennis player ranked 12th in the world, defeated Sam Querrey, ranked 29th, with a score of 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes at the Shanghai Masters, advancing to the second round. Following his recent victory at the Japan Open, Kyrgios expressed fatigue and a lack of enthusiasm during the match, attributing it to tiredness from travel and poor sleep. He also mentioned the inconvenience of traveling to the Qi Zhong Stadium. Last year at the same tournament, Kyrgios was fined for an outburst where he called the event a "circus".

The human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccine, which is currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect against cervical cancer, is also effective against head and neck cancers. These cancers are on the rise, affecting younger, mostly male non-smokers with an average age of 55. Charities and organizations, including Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team, are urging the Welsh government to extend the vaccination to boys. They argue that HPV contributes to 5% of the global cancer burden and that vaccinating boys would be a progressive public health measure. In 2008, 85% of girls in Wales were vaccinated through a school program. The Welsh government is currently awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any decisions on changes to the HPV vaccination program.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old from West Calder High School, passed away from gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Diagnosed in August, he documented his journey on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey, which gained over 28,000 Likes. Despite his illness, Jak maintained a positive attitude and was an avid supporter of Rangers FC, meeting several of its players. He briefly attended a prom organized in his honor but had to leave early due to feeling unwell. Jak received his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy at the event. His cancer spread throughout his body in January, leading doctors to cease treatment. Jak and his family shared many personal moments online, including hospital stays and visits from various sports teams and the cast of Wicked. Following his death, a fundraising football match was planned to raise money for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

In a match that ended Egypt 1, Uganda 0, Abdallah El Said scored the winning goal in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. The game was largely uneventful with few scoring opportunities until the late goal. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside earlier in the match. Egypt's victory sets up a crucial match against Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament, their first since 1978. Ghana had already secured their place in the quarter-finals with a win over Mali. The match was played on a deteriorating pitch in Port-Gentil, where Egypt struggled to break down Uganda's defense for most of the game.

Lancashire County Council has identified land at the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, a town without a station since 1956. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to offer two direct trains per hour to Liverpool. The preferred site, Glenburn Sports College, was chosen after a comparative study and is favored for its size, potential for expansion, and good connectivity. The council is set to begin the process of acquiring the necessary land for this development.
During a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house setup. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, was found with serious injuries on a pavement late Sunday and was dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner from Bad Muender turned himself in to the police. Both individuals are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack remains unclear, and police are seeking witnesses.

The research from Cass Business School, and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, analyzed 4,600 workers and found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are 25% less likely to receive one when comparing like-for-like full-time and part-time workers. The study debunked the "reticent female" theory, showing no evidence that women were hesitant to ask for salary increases due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from stereotypes. The research, based on the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, considered factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. Professor Andrew Oswald from Warwick University suggested that the findings indicate some level of discrimination against women. The study also noted that among workers under 40, both genders asked for and received pay rises at similar rates, suggesting a potential shift in negotiating behavior among younger women, as noted by Dr. Amanda Goodall from Cass Business School.

Oxford City Council has been unable to find a suitable new burial site despite extensive searches and ground investigations, as all potential sites have been discounted due to various issues such as size, ground conditions, high water table, or restrictive covenants. The existing cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. After these are full, only the reopening of family plots, use of reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be possible. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932. The council continues to explore options despite the challenges.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from July 19 to 22, introduces an app that enhances visitor experience through augmented reality. This app allows users to access online content like videos and band interviews by interacting with festival signs and posters. Notable performers include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlighted that this feature not only enriches the on-site experience but also enables global interaction with the festival's atmosphere.
